revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{More citations needed|date=September 2017}} {{Infobox building | name = 666 Fifth Avenue | status = Complete | image = 666 Fifth Avenue by David Shankbone.jpg | image_size = 300px | caption = | location = 666 Fifth Avenue, [[Manhattan]], [[New York (state)|New York]] 10103 | coordinates = {{coord|40.760163|-73.976204|format=dms}} | start_date = | completion_date = 1957 | architect = [[Carson & Lundin]] | owner = [[Brookfield Properties]] 99 year-lease [[Kushner Properties]] ~53–57%
[[Vornado Realty Trust]] ~43–47% | cost = | floor_area = {{convert|1,463,892|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} | top_floor = | floor_count = 41 | references = | map_type = | building_type = Office | antenna_spire = | roof = {{convert|483|ft|m|abbr=on}} | elevator_count = | structural_engineer = | main_contractor = | opening = | developer = Tishman Realty and Construction | management = }} '''666 Fifth Avenue''' is a 41-story [[office building]] on [[Fifth Avenue]] between [[52nd Street (Manhattan)|52nd]] and [[53rd Street (Manhattan)|53rd]] Streets in [[Midtown Manhattan|Midtown]] [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]].{{cite web |url=http://www.tishmanspeyer.com/properties/Property.aspx?id=41 |archivedate=June 28, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070628001201/http://www.tishmanspeyer.com/properties/Property.aspx?id=41 |title=666 Fifth Avenue |website=tishmanspeyer.com |publisher=Tishman Speyer Properties |accessdate=September 30, 2016}} The office tower was designed by [[Carson & Lundin]] and built in 1957 by [[Tishman Realty and Construction]], which sold it when the corporation dissolved in 1976. 666 Fifth Avenue was bought by [[Sumitomo Realty & Development]] in the late 1990s, and [[Tishman Speyer]] bought it back in 2000, adding tenants before selling it yet again to [[Kushner Properties]] in 2007. In August 2018, [[Brookfield Asset Management|Brookfield Properties]] took a 99-year lease on 666 Fifth Avenue. ==Ownership and history== [[Image:666fifth-front.jpg|thumb|250px|left|Front of 666 Fifth Avenue]] ===Construction, Tishman ownership, and sales=== The Tishman family via [[Tishman Realty and Construction]] built the {{convert|1500000|sqft|adj=on}} tower in 1957.{{cite news |url=http://observer.com/2007/01/666-fifth-avenue-deal-closes/|title=666 Fifth Avenue Deal Closes|author=Staff |work=[[The New York Observer]] |date=January 30, 2007}} It was designed by [[Carson & Lundin]], who also simultaneously worked on [[600 Fifth Avenue]] in the nearby [[Rockefeller Center]], and the building was called the Tishman Building. One of its most famous exterior features was the prominent [[666 (number)|666]] address emblazoned on the top of the building. The other distinctive exterior features are embossed aluminum panels. The original design included lobby sculptures by Japanese American artist and landscape architect [[Isamu Noguchi]], including the "Landscape of the Cloud" which consists of sinuously cut thin railings in the ceiling to create a cloud effect. The cloud is also carried into a ceiling-to-floor waterfall. The penthouse was occupied by the Top of the Sixes restaurant, operated by [[Stouffer's]], which closed in 1996.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/18/nyregion/no-more-of-tables-for-two-at-the-top-of-the-sixes.html|title=No More of Tables for Two at the Top of the Sixes|first=David |last=Stout|work=The New York Times |date=September 18, 1996}} For many years the building had a distinctive feature of a T-shaped atrium walk-through open to the sidewalks on 52nd Street, 53rd Street and Fifth Avenue with glass storefronts inside the walk-through. This included a bookstore and another area used for years by [[Alitalia]] Airlines. For many years, the building was the home of [[Benton & Bowles]], a major advertising firm. Tishman Realty dissolved in 1976 and the building was sold for $80 million (about ${{Inflation|US-GDP|80|1976|r=-1}} million in {{inflation-year|US-GDP}}{{inflation-fn|US-GDP}}). In the late 1980s, Japanese firms bought both [[Rockefeller Center]] and 666 Fifth Avenue. The new owner of 666 Fifth was Japanese realty and development company [[Sumitomo Realty & Development|Sumitomo]]. Major changes included replacing the Top of the Sixes restaurant with the Grand Havana Room, a [[cigar bar]] private club.{{cite news |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/grand-havana-room-2013-2?op=1 |title=Tour The Exclusive Cigar Club Where Wall Streeters And Charlie Gasparino Love To Hang Out|first=Julia |last=La Roche|work=[[Business Insider]] |date=February 1, 2013}} The newly reconstituted [[Tishman Speyer Properties]] bought the building for $518 million in 2000 (about ${{Inflation|US-GDP|518|2000|r=-1}} million in {{inflation-year|US-GDP}}{{inflation-fn|US-GDP}}), and about the same time Tishman also bought Rockefeller Center. Shortly after the purchase, Tishman enclosed the atrium walk-through and added a third tenant, [[Hickey Freeman]].{{cite web |url=http://www.thecityreview.com/fifth666.html |work=The Midtown Book |title=The Tishman Building |first=Carter B. |last=Horsley |accessdate=September 30, 2016}} The enclosure cut off the Fifth Avenue entrance, and access now has to be via 52nd or 53rd Street. In 2002 the 666 address on the side of the building was replaced with a [[Citigroup]] logo, and Citigroup is now the building's largest tenant.{{cite web |url=http://nreionline.com/news/Top_Price_for_Top_of_the_Sixes/ |title=Top Price for Top of the Sixes |publisher=National Real Estate Investor |first=Parke |last=Chapman |date=December 12, 2006 |accessdate=September 30, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150203080735/http://nreionline.com/news/Top_Price_for_Top_of_the_Sixes |archive-date=February 3, 2015 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }} The 2006 sale was the third blockbuster deal involving Tishman in two years. In 2005 Tishman bought the [[MetLife Building]] for $1.72 billion (about ${{Inflation|US-GDP|1.72|2005|r=1}} billion in {{inflation-year|US-GDP}}{{inflation-fn|US-GDP}}), setting the previous record.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/04/02/nyregion/metlife-sells-second-tower-in-a-week.html |title=Sells 2nd Building, A Landmark On Park Ave.|first=Anthony |last=Ramirez |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=April 2, 2005}} A month before the 666 sale, Tishman bought [[Stuyvesant Town–Peter Cooper Village]] for $5.4 billion, which was the biggest real estate deal in U.S. history.{{cite news |url =https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/18/nyregion/18stuyvesant.html|title=Sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village Goes Through Despite Some Tenants' Efforts|first=Charles V. |last=Baglidec|work=The New York Times |date =November 18, 2006}} ===Repurposing=== In January 2007, Tishman Speyer, along with the German investment firm TMW, announced the sale of the building to the [[Kushner Properties]] for $1.8 billion (about ${{Inflation|US-GDP|1.8|2006|r=1}} billion in {{inflation-year|US-GDP}}{{inflation-fn|US-GDP}}), at the time the highest price ever paid for an individual building in [[Manhattan]].{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/07/nyregion/07building.html |title=Big Deal, Even in Manhattan: A Tower Goes for $1.8 Billion|first=Charles V. |last=Bagli |work=The New York Times |date=December 7, 2006 |accessdate=September 30, 2016}} This was an unconventional price for such a short building by New York standards, standing at {{convert|483|ft|abbr=on}}. 666 Fifth is not among the [[list of tallest buildings in New York City|top 100 tallest buildings in New York City]], but its high price was mainly because of its location on Fifth Avenue near [[Rockefeller Center]]. Kushner sold the retail condominium portion of 666 Fifth to a [[Stanley Chera]]-led group for $525 million in 2008 (about ${{Inflation|US-GDP|525|2008|r=-1}} million in {{inflation-year|US-GDP}}{{inflation-fn|US-GDP}}).{{cite news|url=http://observer.com/2008/07/carlyle-group-buys-stake-in-666-fifth-retail-for-525-m/ |title=Carlyle Group Buys Stake in 666 Fifth Retail for $525 M. |website=Observer |first=Dana |last=Rubinstein |date=July 1, 2008 |accessdate=September 30, 2016}} In March 2017, reports were made that [[Anbang Insurance Group]] of China was in talks to purchase an interest in the building, based on a value of $2.85 billion ($1.6 billion for the office section, and $1.25 billion for the retail section); some of the alleged terms of the deal were called "unusually favorable," including an exit for [[Vornado Realty Trust]] and retirement of the Kushner organization's remaining debt at 20 cents on the dollar, raising concerns about political influence on the [[presidency of Donald Trump|Donald Trump presidential administration]] due to [[Jared Kushner]]'s position.{{cite news|publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=March 13, 2017|title=Kushners Set to Get $400 Million From Chinese Firm on Tower|author=David Kocieniewski and Caleb Melby |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-03-13/kushners-set-to-get-400-million-from-chinese-on-marquee-tower}} Shortly after the reports were made, Anbang denied that they were looking to invest in the building.{{cite news|publisher=[[Reuters]]|date=March 14, 2017|title=China's Anbang denies report of Kushner property investment|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-anbang-group-kushner-idUSKBN16L2TS}} In March 2017, [[Zaha Hadid Architects]] announced plans for a $12 billion, 1,400 foot skyscraper being developed by the Kushner organization to replace the current building. The new building, to include retail and residential space and a hotel, would be completed by 2025 at the earliest, and would face a park, created by razing a block of current buildings. The developers also plan to change the name to 660 Fifth Avenue, to avoid the diabolical association with the number [[Number of the Beast|666]].{{cite web |first=Dan |last=Howarth |title=Zaha Hadid Architects unveils 666 Fifth Avenue skyscraper for Kushner Companies |url=https://www.dezeen.com/2017/03/23/zaha-hadid-architects-666-fifth-avenue-skyscraper-compared-glass-dildo-architecture-offices/ |work=[[Dezeen]] |date=March 23, 2017 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}}{{cite web |first=Kriston |last=Capps |title=666 Fifth Avenue Is the Perfect Symbol for the Trump Era |url=https://www.citylab.com/design/2017/03/666-fifth-avenue-is-the-perfect-symbol-for-the-trump-era/520563/ |work=[[The Atlantic#CityLab|CityLab]] |date=March 24, 2017 |accessdate=May 27, 2017}} The plans to replace the current building were later withdrawn.{{cite web|title=Kushners are ‘weighing our options’ for the future of 666 Fifth Avenue - Curbed NY|periodical=ny.curbed.com|publisher=|url=https://ny.curbed.com/2018/4/10/17219036/kushner-companies-midtown-666-fifth-avenue-sale|deadurl=|format=|accessdate=April 17, 2018|archiveurl=|archivedate=|last=|date=|year=|month=|day=|language=|pages=|quote=}} In late April 2017, Charles Kushner met with Qatari [[Finance Minister]] [[Ali Sharif Al Emadi|Sharif Al Emadi]] in an attempt to secure funding for the tower from [[Qatar]]'s [[sovereign wealth fund]]. Emadi did not agree to invest Qatar's fund in the project.{{cite news|publisher=[[The Intercept]]|date=March 2, 2018|title=Jared Kushner's Real Estate Firm Sought Money Directly From Qatar Government Weeks Before Blockade|url=https://theintercept.com/2018/03/02/jared-kushner-real-estate-qatar-blockade/|author=Clayton Swisher and Ryan Grim|accessdate=March 6, 2018}} About one month later, the [[2017-18 Qatar diplomatic crisis]] began. Jared Kushner reportedly undermined [[United States Secretary of State]] [[Rex Tillerson]]'s efforts to resolve the crisis.{{cite news|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|title=Trump Team’s Shifts Jolt Some Allies and Soothe Others| author=Mark Landler and Gardiner Harris| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/06/09/world/middleeast/rex-tillerson-calls-for-calm-in-middle-east-standoff-with-qatar.html| date=June 9, 2017| accessdate=March 6, 2018}} In September 2017, the ''Washington Post'' wrote: "With one-fourth of its offices empty, lease revenue does not cover monthly interest payments, according to lending documents. A $1.2 billion mortgage, with escalating interest rates, comes due in 18 months. A ratings agency has classified a $115 million portion of the loan as 'troubled,' and company officials decline to say whether it will be fully repaid."washingtonpost.com / [[Michael Kranish]] and Jonathan O'Connell, September 13, 2017: [https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/kushners-white-house-role-crushed-efforts-to-woo-investors-for-nyc-tower/2017/09/13/723a9732-82c8-11e7-ab27-1a21a8e006ab_story.html ''Kushner's White House role 'crushed' efforts to woo investors for NYC tower''] Due to the large amount of debt owed on the tower, Vornado Realty Trust, which owned 49.5 percent of the tower, said in February 2018 that it planned to sell its stake in the building.{{cite web | last=Melby | first=Caleb | title=Kushners’ Indebted Tower May See Vornado Unload Its Stake | website=Bloomberg.com | date=February 12, 2018 | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-02-12/vornado-doesn-t-plan-to-hold-stake-in-kushner-building-for-long | access-date=June 2, 2018}} Vornado's stake in the property was subsequently sold to Kushner Cos. on June 1, 2018.{{cite web | last=Grant | first=Peter | title=Kushner Cos. Signs Deal to Buy Remaining Stake in 666 Fifth Ave. | website=WSJ | date=June 2, 2018 | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/kushner-cos-signs-deal-to-buy-remaining-stake-in-666-fifth-ave-1527898795 | access-date=June 2, 2018}}{{cite web | last=Melby | first=Caleb | title=Kushner Buys 666 Fifth Stake, Ending Rocky Vornado Partnership | website=Bloomberg.com | date=June 1, 2018 | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-01/vornado-to-sell-its-stake-in-troubled-666-fifth-to-kushner-cos | access-date=June 2, 2018}} In August 2018, Brookfield Asset Management took a 99-year lease on 666 Fifth Avenue.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/08/03/nyregion/kushners-building-fifth-avenue-brookfield-lease.html|title=Deal Gives Kushners Cash Infusion on 666 Fifth Avenue|access-date=November 20, 2018|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://ny.curbed.com/2018/8/6/17654692/kushner-companies-brookfield-666-fifth-avenue-deal|title=Kushner Companies finally makes a deal to offload its troubled Midtown tower|work=Curbed NY|access-date=November 20, 2018}} ==Tenants== * [[Brooks Brothers]] and the [[NBA Store]] became the initial ground-floor tenants. Brooks Brothers moved out in 2009, as well as [[Hickey Freeman]] in May of that year. The NBA Store closed in February 2011. * The new [[Hollister Co.]] Epic New York flagship moved in during 2010, and [[Uniqlo]] occupies {{convert|90000|sqft|m2}} on the ground, second, and third floors.{{cite press release |url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20100420006412/en/Japanese-Retail-Phenomenon-Uniqlo-Selects-666-Avenue |title=Japanese Retail Phenomenon Uniqlo Selects 666 Fifth Avenue for Global Flagship Store |website=BusinessWire.com |date=April 20, 2010 |place=New York |accessdate=September 30, 2016}}{{cite news |work=[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]] |url=http://www.fastcompany.com/magazine/167/uniqlo-tadashi-yanai |title=Cheap, Chic, And Made For All: How Uniqlo Plans To Take Over Casual Fashion |date=June 18, 2012 |first=Jeff |last=Chu |accessdate=September 30, 2016}} The Hollister flagship opened in the later part of 2010 and features a live video feed from [[Huntington Beach, California]] displayed on 179 flat-screen TVs outside the store along with wave pools.{{cite news |last=Feran |first=Tim |url=http://www.dispatch.com/live/content/business/stories/2010/12/07/surfs-up-at-newest-hollister-store-in-nyc.html |title=Surf's up at newest Hollister store in NYC |work=[[The Columbus Dispatch]] |date=December 7, 2010|accessdate=December 26, 2010}} * The building has also become an attractive location for law firms, hosting the New York offices of [[Schiff Hardin]], [[Vinson & Elkins]], [[Norton Rose Fulbright]], and [[Orrick, Herrington & Sutcliffe]].{{cite news |url=http://www.schiffhardin.com/offices/new-york |title=New York |publisher=[[Norton Rose Fulbright]] |accessdate=August 21, 2014}}{{cite news |url=http://www.velaw.com/offices/NewYork.aspx |title=New York |publisher=[[Schiff Hardin]] |accessdate=September 3, 2017}}{{cite news |url=http://www.nortonrosefulbright.com/us/offices/new-york/ |title=New York |publisher=[[Norton Rose Fulbright]] |accessdate=August 21, 2014}} * In addition to law firms, 666 Fifth Avenue houses the hedge fund [[Atlantic Investment Management]], the hedge fund [[Millennium Management, LLC]], the private equity firm [[AEA Investors]], and the investment bank [[William Blair & Company]].{{Cn|date=July 2018}} * The headquarters for [[DC Comics]] was located at 666 Fifth Avenue before moving to 1700 Broadway in the 1990s.{{Cn|date=July 2018}} ==Subway entrance== The building contains an entrance to the [[New York City Subway]]'s [[Fifth Avenue/53rd Street (IND Queens Boulevard Line)|Fifth Avenue/53rd Street]] station, which is served by the {{NYCS trains|Queens 53rd}}.{{cite NYCS map|Midtown East}} When the Hollister Co. store was opened, polished gray columns were placed in the lobby near the elevators and changes were made to the [[New York City Subway|subway]] entrance at the base of the building. ==In popular culture== The opening lunch scene for the movie ''[[The Wolf of Wall Street (2013 film)|The Wolf of Wall Street]]'' was filmed in the former Top of the Sixes restaurant.{{cite web | title=The scandalous history behind Kushner’s ritzy Midtown building | website=New York Post | date=April 18, 2017 | url=https://nypost.com/2017/04/18/the-scandalous-history-behind-kushners-ritzy-midtown-building/ | access-date=February 20, 2018|quote=In his 2007 memoir, “The Wolf of Wall Street,” Jordan Belfort recalled lunching at Top of the Sixes with a pal from LF Rothschild, downstairs. “It was where Masters of the Universe could get blitzed on martinis and exchange war stories,” Belfort wrote, as depicted in the 2013 movie.}} The 1959 documentary film ''Skyscraper'' [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GeE8wf4JSbU| Skyscraper 1959 40780 HD-PeriscopeFilm on YouTube] was about the construction of 666 Fifth Avenue.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kqcYAQAAIAAJ&pg=PA548|title=The Encyclopedia of Film|last=Monaco|first=James|date=1991|publisher=Perigee Books|isbn=9780399516047|language=en}} The film's director [[Shirley Clarke]] described it as a "musical comedy about the building of a skyscraper." ''Skyscraper'' was nominated for an [[Academy Award for Live Action Short Film|Academy Award]] in 1960.{{Cite news|url=https://www.oscars.org/oscars/ceremonies/1960|title=The 32nd Academy Awards {{!}} 1960|work=Oscars.org {{!}} Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences|access-date=January 22, 2018|language=en}} Beginning in [[Mad Men (season 4)|season 4]] of ''[[Mad Men]]'', when SCD&P move into the Time-Life Building, the "666" on top of the building can be seen in many scenes, through the window just outside of Don Draper’s office. {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=tishmanbuilding-newyorkcity-ny-usa Profile of building] on [[Emporis]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1957]] [[Category:Fifth Avenue]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Manhattan]] [[Category:Citigroup buildings]] [[Category:Carson and Lundin buildings]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:Kushner family]] [[Category:Roth family]]

revision.comment: The Art News in the 1930s
revision.text:
{{use mdy dates|date=December 2011}} {{use American English|date=August 2014}} {{infobox magazine | image_file = ARTnews Cover February 2014.jpg | image_alt = | image_caption = February 2014 cover of ''ARTnews'' | publisher = | editor = Sarah Douglas<ref name="ng"/> | editor_title = | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | category = Visual arts | frequency = Quarterly | format = | total_circulation = 180,000 | circulation_year = 2013 | founder = James Clarence Hyde | founded = | firstdate = {{start date and age|1902|paren=yes}} as ''Hydes Weekly Art News'' | company = [http://www.artmediaholdings.com Art Media Holdings] | country = United States | based = [[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]] | language = English | website = {{URL|artnews.com}} | issn = 0004-3273 | oclc = 586878190 }} '''''ARTnews''''' is an American visual-arts magazine, based in [[New York City]]. It covers art from ancient to [[Post-modernism|contemporary]] times. It includes news dispatches from correspondents, investigative reports, reviews of exhibitions, and profiles of artists and collectors.
==History and operations== The magazine was founded by James Clarence Hyde in 1902 as '''''Hydes Weekly Art News''''' and was originally published eleven times a year.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Guide to Serial Publications Founded Prior to 1918 and Now Or Recently Current in Boston, Cambridge, and Vicinity|last=Homer|first=Thomas Johnston|publisher=Trustees of the Public Library|year=1922|isbn=|location=Boston, Massachusetts|pages=20|quote=|via=https://books.google.com/books?id=2qVEAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA20&ots=rVDu3_6L2G&dq=artnews%201902&pg=PA20#v=onepage&q=artnews%201902&f=false}}</ref><ref>[http://www.copyideas.com/wp-content/uploads/2008/03/mcleans_1902.pdf "McLean’s 1902 Letter"] [[PDF|PDF format]].</ref>
From vol. 3, no. 52 (November 5, 1904) to vol. 21, no. 18 (February 10, 1923), the magazine was published as '''''American Art News'''''.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Guide to Serial Publications Founded Prior to 1918 and Now Or Recently Current in Boston, Cambridge, and Vicinity|last=Homer|first=Thomas Johnston|publisher=Trustees of the Public Library|year=1922|isbn=|location=Boston, Massachusetts|pages=20|quote=|via=https://books.google.com/books?id=2qVEAQAAMAAJ&lpg=PA20&ots=rVDu3_6L2G&dq=artnews%201902&pg=PA20#v=onepage&q=artnews%201902&f=false}}</ref>From February 1923 to the present, the magazine has been published as ''The Art News'' then ''ARTnews''.<ref>[http://catalogue.nla.gov.au/Record/746445 ARTNews], National Library of Australia.</ref>
The magazine's [[art critic]]s and correspondents include [[Arthur Danto]], Linda Yablonsky, Barbara Pollock, Margarett Loke, Hilarie Sheets, [[Yale School of Art]] dean [[Robert Storr (art academic)|Robert Storr]],<ref>Staff (undated). [http://newyorkmetro.com/news/features/influentials/16900/ "The Most Influential Americans in Art"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080720001527/http://newyorkmetro.com/news/features/influentials/16900 |date=July 20, 2008 }}. ''New York''. Retrieved August 10, 2014.</ref> Doug McClemont and [[Museum of Modern Art]] director [[Glenn D. Lowry]].<ref name="nyt2007">{{registration required|date=August 2014}} [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/16/arts/design/16moma.html "Donors Sweetened Director's Pay at MoMA"]. February 16, 2007. ''The New York Times''.</ref>
In April 2014, Milton and Judith Esterow, the magazine's owners since 1972, sold the publication to Skate Capital Corp., a private asset-management firm owned by Sergey Skaterschikov.<ref><!--{{Dead link|date=August 2014}}-->{{registration required|date=August 2014}} Cohen, Patricia (April 8, 2014). [http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2014/04/08/artnews-sold-to-private-firm/ "ARTnews Sold to Private Company"]. ''The New York Times''.</ref> It was later revealed that Skate Capital was acting on behalf of the Polish company Abbey House, which renamed itself ARTNEWS SA.<ref name="ng">{{Cite news|issn=0458-3035|last=Ng|first=David|title= ARTnews Magazine Gets New Leadership, With a Twist|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=August 10, 2014|date=June 27, 2014|url= http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/arts/culture/la-et-cm-artnews-magazine-new-leadership-20140627-story.html}}</ref>
Following this change in ownership the magazine merged with ''[[Art in America]]'' in June 2015, owned by Brant Publication's BMP Media Holdings, LLC.<ref name="sarc"/> In October 2015 the monthly frequency of ''ARTnews'' was switched to quarterly.<ref name="sarc">{{cite news|author=Sarah Cascone|title=‘ARTnews’ Magazine Ceases Monthly Print Publication After 113 Years|url=https://news.artnet.com/art-world/artnews-quarterly-after-merger-339030|accessdate=December 10, 2016|work=ARTnet|date=October 9, 2015}}</ref> In 2016, Brant Publications took full control of BMP.<ref>{{Cite web| title = BMP Media Holdings Completes Transaction to Assume U.S. Assets of Artnews S.A.| accessdate = 2018-02-19| date = 2016-05-27| url = https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160526006566/en/BMP-Media-Holdings-Completes-Transaction-Assume-U.S.}}</ref>
The magazine, along with ''[[Art in America]]'', ''[[The Magazine ANTIQUES]]'', and ''Modern Magazine'' have been owned by [http://www.artmediaholdings.com Art Media Holdings] since June 2016 and are based in Soho, New York City.
==Awards== The magazine has won the [[George Polk Award]], the [[National Magazine Award]] for General Excellence, the [[National Headliner Award]] and the [[National Arts Club]] Distinguished Citation for Merit.<ref>{{registration required|date=August 2014}} {{cite news|author=Rachel Lee Harris|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/06/arts/design/06arts-REPORTFINDSA_BRF.html?_r=1&ref=design|title=Report Finds Abundance of Fake Russian Paintings|location=Russia|work=The New York Times|date=July 5, 2009|accessdate=December 4, 2011}}</ref><ref><!--page seems OK now{{Dead link|date=August 2014}} may be temporary; page never loads (like a continual reload loop-->{{cite web|author=Janhavi K. Sapra |url=https://blogs.forbes.com/billions/2010/06/23/billionaire-art-aficionados/ |title=Billionaire Art Aficionados |work=Forbes|date=June 23, 2010 |accessdate=September 17, 2014}}</ref><ref><!--{{Dead link|date=August 2014}}-->{{cite web|last=Harris |first=Marlys |url=http://luxuryinstitute.com/graphics/doclib/2007/CNNMoney6217LI.pdf|title=How to Marry a Billionaire|work=CNN Money|date=July 3, 2007|accessdate=September 17, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author = Ng, David | url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/culturemonster/2010/06/la-billionaires-among-artnews-top-200-collectors-for-2010.html |title=L.A. Billionaires Among ARTnews' Top 200 Collectors for 2010|work=Culture Monster (blog of the ''Los Angeles Times'')|date=June 30, 2010 |accessdate= August 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author = Gluckman, Nell|url=http://www.nysun.com/arts/artnews-names-top-200-collectors/80774/ |title=ARTnews Names Top 200 Collectors |work= [[The New York Sun]] |date=June 27, 2008 |accessdate= August 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Sandler |first=Linda |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aLNnz1mfWT40&refer=muse |title= Koons, Hirst Aren't on ARTnews List of Famous Future Artists |work=Bloomberg News|date=October 30, 2007 |accessdate=August 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/the-nouveau-fakes-russian-avantgarde-forgeries-1772831.html |title=The Nouveau Fakes: Russian Avant-Garde Forgeries |work=The Independent|date=August 16, 2009 |accessdate= August 10, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author = Staff | url=http://www.koreaherald.com/lifestyle/Detail.jsp?newsMLId=20100728000587 |title=Kim Chang-il Among World's Top 200 Collectors |work=The Korea Herald|date=July 28, 2010 |accessdate= August 10, 2014}}</ref>
==The ''ARTNews'' Top 200 Collectors== The ''ARTNews'' Top 200 list is released annually and contains the top individual art collectors from around the world based on interviews with collectors, curators, dealers, auction houses, and museums. Those on the list are also surveyed, and their responses are used to inform trends and provide data, such as a breakdown of where the most top art collectors live (the United States<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2013/07/11/where-do-the-worlds-top-art-collectors-live/|title=Where do the world's top art collectors live|last=|first=|date=|website=Foreign Policy|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>).
Collectors on the list are profiled with a brief biography focused on the type of art that they collect (contemporary, post war, modern, etc.) and includes their city or cities of residence, a photo, their source of wealth and the years they have been on the Top 200 list, as many collectors are on it for multiple years. The list released in September 2018 includes [[Leonard Lauder]], Edythe and [[Eli Broad]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/edythe-l-and-eli-broad/|title=ARTNews Top 200: Edythe and Eli Broad|last=|first=|date=|website=Art News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>, [http://www.artnews.com/top200/eisenberg-family/ Rebecca and Warren Eisenberg], [http://www.artnews.com/top200/alison-and-peter-w-klein/ Alison and Peter Klein], Marsha and [[Jeffrey E. Perelman|Jeffrey Perelman]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/marsha-and-jeffrey-perelman/|title=ARTNews Top 200 Collectors: Marsha and Jeffrey Perelman|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>, [http://www.artnews.com/top200/tatsumi-sato/ Tatsumi Sako], Sheri and [[Howard Schultz]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.artnews.com/top200/sheri-and-howard-schultz/|title=ARTNews Top 200 Collectors: Sheri and Howard Schultz|last=|first=|date=|website=Art News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 29, 2018}}</ref>. The full list is announced in both the print and online versions of the magazine.

{{distinguish|Adam Peaty}} {{Infobox NASCAR driver |name = Adam Petty |birth_date = {{birth date|mf=yes|1980|7|10}} |death_date = {{death date and age|mf=yes|2000|5|12|1980|7|10}} |birth_name = Adam Kyler Petty |birth_place = [[Trenton, New Jersey]], U.S. |death_place = [[Loudon, New Hampshire]], U.S. |death_cause = [[Basilar skull fracture]] from crash in Turn 3 of practice for the [[2000 NASCAR Busch Series#Busch 200|2000 Busch 200]] |Total_Cup_Races = 1 |Years_In_Cup = 1 |Best_Cup_Pos = 58th ([[2000 NASCAR Winston Cup Series|2000]]) |Prev_Cup_Pos = 58th |Previous_Year = 2000 |First_Cup_Race = [[2000 NASCAR Winston Cup Series|2000]] [[2000 DirecTV 500|DirecTV 500]] ([[Texas Motor Speedway|Texas]]) |Last_Cup_Race = |First_Cup_Win = |Last_Cup_Win = |Cup_Wins = 0 |Cup_Top_Tens = 0 |Cup_Poles = 0 |Total_Busch_Races = 47 |Years_In_Busch = 3 |Best_Busch_Pos = 20th ([[1999 NASCAR Busch Series|1999]]) |First_Busch_Race = [[1998 NASCAR Busch Series|1998]] [[CarQuest Auto Parts 250]] ([[Gateway International Raceway|Gateway]]) |Last_Busch_Race = [[2000 NASCAR Busch Series|2000]] [[Hardee's 250]] ([[Richmond International Raceway|Richmond]]) |First_Busch_Win = |Last_Busch_Win = |Busch_Wins = 0 |Busch_Top_Tens = 4 |Busch_Poles = 0 |Total_Truck_Races = 2 |Years_In_Truck = 1 |First_Truck_Race = [[1999 NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series|1999]] [[Virginia Is For Lovers 200]] ([[Richmond International Raceway|Richmond]]) |Last_Truck_Race = [[1999 NASCAR Craftsman Truck Series|1999]] [[O'Reilly 300]] ([[Texas Motor Speedway|Texas]]) |Truck_Wins = 0 |Truck_Top_Tens = 1 |Truck_Poles = 0 }} '''Adam Kyler Petty''' (July 10, 1980 – May 12, 2000) was a professional racing driver. He was the first fourth-generation driver in [[NASCAR]] history. ==Early life== Petty was raised in [[High Point, North Carolina]] into [[stock car]] racing "royalty". The son of [[Kyle Petty]], he was widely expected to become the next great Petty, following in the footsteps of his father, grandfather [[Richard Petty|Richard]], and great-grandfather [[Lee Petty|Lee]]. He was the first known fourth-generation athlete in all of modern American motor sports to participate in the chosen profession of his generations. ==Racing career== Petty began his career in 1998, shortly after he turned 18, in the [[ARCA RE/MAX Series]]. Like his father Kyle, he won his first ARCA race, driving the #45 [[Pontiac]] at [[Lowe's Motor Speedway]]. Petty moved to [[NASCAR Nationwide Series|NASCAR Busch Series]] full-time in 1999, driving the #45 [[Chevrolet]]. Petty finished sixth in his first Busch Series race at [[Daytona International Speedway|Daytona]] and had a best finish of fourth place, though he also failed to qualify for three of the Busch races. Petty finished the 1999 season 20th overall in points. [[Petty Enterprises]] planned to have Petty run a second Busch season in 2000, while giving him seven starts in the [[2000 NASCAR Winston Cup Series]], in preparation for a full Winston Cup campaign in 2001. He struggled early in the Busch season, but managed to qualify in his first attempt at Winston Cup during the [[2000 DirecTV 500|DirecTV 500]] at [[Texas Motor Speedway]] on April 2. He qualified 33rd and ran in the middle of the pack most of the day before his engine expired, forcing him to finish 40th. Adam never got to race alongside his father. Kyle failed to qualify and eventually relieved an ill [[Elliott Sadler]], but Adam was already out of the race. [[Lee Petty]], Adam's great-grandfather, and 3-time NASCAR Champion, lived to see his Winston debut, but died just three days later. ==Death== In a practice session for the [[Busch 200 (New Hampshire)|Busch 200]] race{{cite web|url=http://nationwide.nascar.com/nationwide-series/races/2000/results-official/12/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-08-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814172208/http://nationwide.nascar.com/nationwide-series/races/2000/results-official/12/ |archivedate=2011-08-14 |df= }} at the [[New Hampshire Motor Speedway]], Petty's throttle stuck wide open at turn three, causing the car to hit the outside wall virtually head on. Petty was killed instantly when he suffered a [[basilar skull fracture]].{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/motorsports/news/2000/05/12/petty_crash/ |title=CNNSI.com - Motor Sports - Adam Petty killed in practice crash at NHIS - Friday July 07, 2000 02:33 PM |publisher=Sportsillustrated.cnn.com |date=2000-07-07 |accessdate=2013-07-20}} He was 19 years old. Petty's death, along with 1998 Winston Cup [[NASCAR Rookie of the Year|Rookie of the Year]] [[Kenny Irwin Jr.]]'s in the same corner at the same track eight weeks later,{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/auto/nascar/news/2000/0707/623002.html |title=ESPN.com - Auto Racing - Irwin killed in same turn as Adam Petty |publisher=Espn.go.com |date= |accessdate=2013-07-20}} led NASCAR to mandate the use of a [[kill switch]] on the steering wheel and the adoption of the [[Whelen Modified Tour]] [[restrictor plate]] for the September Cup race; the plate was abandoned after that race. These two adjustments addressed the cause of the deadly accidents, but did not address the basilar skull fractures suffered by both drivers. The [[HANS device|HANS]] or [[Hutchens device|Hutchens]] devices, designed to prevent the rapid-deceleration head-and-neck movements associated with the injury that Petty and Irwin Jr. suffered, was not mandated by NASCAR until 2001, after similar injuries and deaths of [[Tony Roper (racing driver)|Tony Roper]], [[Dale Earnhardt]] and ARCA driver [[Blaise Alexander]]. Kyle Petty, who drove the No. 44 car at the time of the crash, drove Adam's No. 45 car in the Busch Series for the remainder of 2000. He then used the No. 45 in the Cup Series throughout the rest of his driving career.{{cite web|url=http://www.racing-reference.info/driver/pettyky01 |title=Kyle Petty Career Statistics |publisher=Racing-Reference.info |date=1960-06-02 |accessdate=2013-07-20}} ==Legacy== [[File:George W. Bush at Victory Junction Gang Camp - Randleman, N.C. with NASCAR drivers.jpg|thumb|President [[George W. Bush]] is joined at Adam's Race Shop on the grounds of Victory Junction Gang Camp, Inc., in Randleman, N.C., by Kyle and Richard Petty, [[Michael Waltrip]] and [[Jimmie Johnson]].]] In October 2000, five months after Petty's death, his family partnered with [[Paul Newman]] and the [[Hole in the Wall Gang Camp]] to begin the Victory Junction Gang Camp in [[Randleman, North Carolina]] as a memorial to Petty. The camp has received support from many NASCAR drivers, teams, and sponsors, including Cup Series sponsor Sprint, which has placed a replica of Petty's 1998 car in the camp. The camp began operation in 2004 and is an official charity of NASCAR. Petty also appears as a special guest driver in the video games ''[[NASCAR 2000]]'', ''[[NASCAR Rumble]]'', ''[[NASCAR 2001]]'' and ''[[NASCAR Arcade]]''. In December 2013, his brother Austin named his newborn son after Adam in tribute.{{cite web|last=Richter|first=Josh|url=http://msn.foxsports.com/nascar/shake-and-bake/gen-5-petty-the-king-meets-his-great-grandson-adam-121613|title=Gen-5 Petty: "The King" meets his great-grandson Adam|publisher=[[Fox Sports (United States)|Fox Sports]]|date=2013-12-16|accessdate=2013-12-16|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131217052751/http://msn.foxsports.com/nascar/shake-and-bake/gen-5-petty-the-king-meets-his-great-grandson-adam-121613|archivedate=2013-12-17|df=}} ==Motorsports career results== ===NASCAR=== ([[Template:NASCAR driver results legend|key]]) ('''Bold''' – Pole position awarded by qualifying time. revision.text:
'''Andrew Jameson''' [[Privy Council of Ireland|PC (Ire)]] [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] (17 August 1855 – 15 February 1941) was a Scottish-born Irish public servant, politician and businessman.
Jameson was born in [[Alloa]], [[Clackmannanshire]], [[Scotland]]. He was educated at [[London International College]], [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] and [[Trinity College, Dublin]].<ref>{{acad|id=JM873A|name=Jameson, Andrew}}</ref> From 1896 to 1898 he was Governor of the [[Bank of Ireland]], remaining a director until 1941. In 1902 he was [[High Sheriff of County Dublin]]. He was also chairman of the [[Commissioners of Irish Lights|Irish Lights Commission]], which administered lighthouses in Ireland. He was president of the [[Dublin Chamber of Commerce]] in 1921–22.
In 1917 he was a member of the unsuccessful [[Irish Convention]]. He was appointed to the [[Privy Council of Ireland]] in the 1921 New Year Honours, entitling him to the style "The Right Honourable".
From 1922 to 1936 Jameson served as a [[Seanad Éireann (Irish Free State)|Senator]] of the [[Irish Free State]].<ref name=oireachtas_db>{{cite web|url=http://oireachtas.ie/members-hist/default.asp?housetype=1&HouseNum=1922&MemberID=1399&ConstID=214|title=Mr. Andrew Jameson|work=Oireachtas Members Database|accessdate=4 April 2015}}</ref> As a member of the Memorial Committee set up to establish the [[Irish National War Memorial Gardens]], in December 1930 he advised [[W. T. Cosgrave]], President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State, who was very interested in bringing the memorial to fruition, on the suitability of the site running along the south bank of the [[River Liffey]]; this site was eventually decided upon by Cosgrave and agreed by the committee.
Jameson was also chairman of the whiskey distillers [[Jameson Irish Whiskey|John Jameson & Son Ltd]].
In 1877 he married Grace (1854–1922), daughter of Dr William Malachy Burke of [[Loughrea]]. They had four children, including the painter [[Harriet Kirkwood]]. He married secondly, in 1924, Ruth Hart, daughter of [[George Vaughan Hart (academic)|George Vaughan Hart]] of [[Howth]], County Dublin. They had no children.<ref>[http://www.cgoakley.org/efa/1851HHM.html Andrew Jameson, Jr.]</ref>
==Footnotes== {{Reflist}}
