revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=July 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2017}}
{{Infobox person | name = Nubar Gulbenkian | image = Nubar gulbenkian.jpg | caption = | birth_name = Nubar Sarkis Gulbenkian | birth_date = 2 June 1896 | birth_place = [[Kadıköy]], [[Ottoman Empire]]<ref>{{cite web | title = Obits: "Gu" – "Gz" | work = Caskets on Parade | publisher = C.O.P. Audit Committee | date = 1 April 2007 | url = http://daggy.name/cop/bkofdead/obits-gu.htm#GulbenkianNubarSarkis | accessdate =28 January 2008}}</ref> | death_date = {{Death date and age|df=yes|1972|1|10|1896|6|2}} | death_place = [[Cannes]], France | education = [[Harrow School]] | alma_mater = [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] | occupation = Businessman | nationality = Armenian | parents = [[Calouste Gulbenkian]] | spouse = {{ubl|Herminia Fejo (m.1922)|Dora Freeland (m.1928)|Marie Berthe Edmée de Ayala (m.1944)}} }}
'''Nubar Sarkis Gulbenkian''' ({{lang-hy| Նուպար Սարգիս Կիւլպէնկեան}}; 2 June 1896 – 10 January 1972) was an [[Armenians|Armenian]] business magnate and [[Playboy (lifestyle)|socialite]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/2726896/A-man-with-a-passion-for-Rollers.html |title=A man with a passion for Rollers |work=The Daily Telegraph |date=14 February 2004 |accessdate=9 March 2016}}</ref> born in the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] empire.
==Early years== The son of [[Calouste Gulbenkian]], he was born in [[Kadıköy]], [[Ottoman Empire]] but fled from the country when he was a few weeks old due to the [[Hamidian massacres]] of Armenians.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gulbenkian|first1=Nubar S.|title=Pantaraxia: The Autobiography of Nubar Gulbenkian|date=1965|publisher=Hutchinson & Company|page=10|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bsYQAQAAIAAJ|quote=I was their first-born. I was only a few weeks old when we left Kadi Keui and fled from Turkey, for the year 1896 was the time of the Armenian massacres.}}</ref> Taken by his father to England, he was educated at [[Harrow School]], [[Trinity College, Cambridge]] and in Germany. He was admitted as a student to the [[Middle Temple]] on 18 October 1917, but was not [[Called to the Bar]]. As a consequence of his educational background Gulbenkian saw himself as British and strove to live up to the model of the English gentleman. As such, during World War II he undertook some amateur sabotage in [[Vichy France]] on behalf of the United Kingdom.<ref name="ReferenceA">N. Gulbenkian, ''Portrait in Oil: The Autobiography of Nubar Gulbenkian'', New York: Simon and Schuster, 1965</ref> Despite this he was also attached to the Iranian Embassy in London in an honorary role (as he held Iranian citizenship) whilst he regained his Turkish citizenship in 1965.<ref name="last">{{cite news | title = Last of the Big Spenders | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date = 24 January 1972 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,905691,00.html | accessdate =28 January 2008}}</ref> This however had helped him during the war as his neutral passport allowed him to cross between France and Spain with little trouble and thus gain access to British intelligence in [[Gibraltar]].<ref>Sherri Greene Ottis, ''Silent Heroes: Downed Airmen and the French Underground'', p. 78</ref>
==Business== [[File:1956 Rolls-Royce Silver Wraith 'Perspex Roof' motif - Flickr - exfordy.jpg|thumb|Mascot, Gulbenkian's Rolls-Royce]] Gulbenkian began as an unpaid worker for his father, who was as noted for his miserly tendencies as his son would be for his spending, but later sued his father for $10 million, bizarrely after a refusal by the company to allow him $4.50 for a lunch of chicken in [[tarragon]] jelly.<ref name="last"/> Ultimately the incident contributed to Calouste Gulbenkian's decision to leave $420 million of his fortune to the [[Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation]] in Portugal.<ref name="last"/>
Although he ultimately inherited $2.5 million from his father, as well as more in a settlement from the Foundation, Gulbenkian also became independently wealthy through his own oil dealings.<ref name="last"/> He was initially the protégé of [[Henri Deterding]] at [[Royal Dutch Shell]]<ref name="ReferenceA"/> but later made an independent fortune which allowed him to live a highly extravagant lifestyle.
==Eccentricity== Gulbenkian's long beard, monocle and the orchid in his buttonhole which was replaced daily led to him becoming noted for a fairly eccentric life, with a number of stories building up around his name. Indeed, his character was summed up by an associate who claimed that "Nubar is so tough that every day he tires out three stockbrokers, three horses and three women".<ref name="last"/> He was a regular face on the international playboy scene.
An aficionado of the [[Hackney carriage]], he frequently stated that 'It turns on a [[Sixpence (British coin)|sixpence]], whatever that is!' He even had two [[Austin FX4]] cabs converted to his own specifications and, despite their somewhat bizarre appearance, one of the vehicles sold for £23,000 in 1993.<ref>{{cite web | last = Adams | first = Keith | title = Specialist conversions | work = Austin Rover Online | date = 17 August 2004 | url = http://austin-rover.co.uk/index.htm?ado6convf.htm | accessdate =28 January 2008}}</ref>
He was an early guest on the [[BBC]] series ''[[Face to Face (British TV series)|Face to Face]]'' in 1959, but refused to sign a contract or accept a fee for his appearance. During the interview he attacked the Trustees of the Gulbenkian Foundation in what amounted to virtual slander.<ref>[[Asa Briggs]] ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=0pRGjVGtUvwC&pg=PA170 The History of Broadcasting in the United Kingdom, Volume V]'', Oxford University Press, 1995, p. 170</ref> Following his appearance, he sued the Corporation to be given a copy of the episode, which he claimed had been promised in lieu of a fee, although the suit was not successful.<ref>{{cite web | last = Burnett | first = Hugh | title = Nubar Gulbenkian interview | work = Memoryshare | publisher = BBC | date = 23 November 2007 | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/dna/memoryshare/derby/A29457895 | accessdate =28 January 2008}}</ref>
A well-known gourmet, he was quoted as saying that 'the best number for a dinner party is two – myself and a damn good head waiter.'<ref>{{cite web | title = Nubar Gulbenkian quotes | publisher = ThinkExist.com Quotations | url = http://thinkexist.com/quotes/nubar_gulbenkian/ | accessdate =28 January 2008}}</ref> Other stories attached to his name include giving his position in life on a [[market research]] form as 'enviable'.
==Personal life== He was married three times, "I've had good wives, as wives go, and as wives go, two of them went". In 1922, he married Herminia Fejo. In 1928, he married Dora Freeland (aka Doré Plowden) in London.<ref>[https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:QV8M-CGWQ Person Details for Nubar S Gulbenkian]</ref> He courted Marie Berthe Edmée de Ayala, daughter of the French champagne tycoon [[Louis d'Ayala]], for 14 years before they married in 1948. He had no children.<ref name="NYTobit">{{cite news|last1=Krebs|first1=Albin|title=Nubar Gulbenkian, Oil Millionaire, Dies|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1972/01/12/archives/nubar-gulbenkian-oil-millionaire-dies-nubar-gulbenkian-oil.html|accessdate=4 February 2017|work=The New York Times|date=12 January 1972}}</ref>
He lived at Arlington House, a block of flats close to London's Ritz Hotel, and at a former rectory in [[Hoggeston]], near Bletchley, Buckinghamshire.<ref name="NYTobit" />
He died on 10 January 1972 at the English Hospital in [[Cannes]], France, and had lived nearby at his "sumptuous estate" the Domaine des Colles at [[Valbonne]].<ref name="NYTobit" />
==Will== Controversy continued to follow him after his death due to the vague nature of his father's [[Will (law)|will]], which appeared to suggest that everybody Nubar was employed by or stayed with during his life should receive some money (See ''[[Re Gulbenkian's Settlements]]'' [1970] AC 553). The case was eventually taken to the [[House of Lords]] before settlement.<ref>Alastair Hudson, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=jkzrDLuWBNIC&pg=PA95&lpg=PA95&dq=%22nubar+gulbenkian%22&source=web&ots=1G0XmuvA5_&sig=c5_s6C9qdj92-wLpcAzlGNrix2k Equity & Trusts]'', p.95</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.jamd.com/search?assettype=g&assetid=2663787&text=%2522Nubar+Gulbenkian%2522 Picture of Gulbenkian] *[http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,905691,00.html ''Time'' profile of Gulbenkian] *[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/motoring/2726896/A-man-with-a-passion-for-Rollers.html ''Telegraph'' article on Gulbenkian's Rolls Royces]
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gulbenkian, Nubar}} [[Category:1896 births]] [[Category:1972 deaths]] [[Category:Alumni of Trinity College, Cambridge]] [[Category:Armenian businesspeople]] [[Category:Armenian businesspeople in the oil industry]] [[Category:Businesspeople in the oil industry]] [[Category:Armenians of the Ottoman Empire]] [[Category:People educated at Harrow School]] [[Category:Socialites]] [[Category:People from Kadıköy]] [[Category:Survivors of the Hamidian massacres]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{Use British English|date=February 2018}} {{multiple| {{primary sources|date=August 2015}} {{COI|date=August 2015}} {{advert|date=August 2015}} }} 'Open to Export' is a free online information service from [[The Institute of Export & International Trade]], dedicated to helping small UK businesses get ready to export and expand internationally.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://opentoexport.com/info/about/|title=Open to Export - About Us & Our Service|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref> It provides webinars and articles covering five different stages of international trade: 'Getting started', 'Selecting a market', 'Reaching customers', 'Pricing and getting paid' and 'Delivery and documentation'.
== Export Action Plan == The 'Export Action Plan<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://opentoexport.com/info/export-action-plan/|title=Open to Export - Export Action Plan Information|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>' is an online planning tool on Open to Export that allows businesses to take ownership of their international strategy. It asks companies to answer questions and set actions along the five different steps to export success, from getting started to delivery and documentation. Once completed, the company can download a PDF report of their export strategy, which they can take to their bank, adviser, or submit to Open to Export's quarterly competitions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://opentoexport.com/info/export-action-plan-competition/|title=Open to Export - Export Action Plan Competition Info|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
=== Export Action Plan Competitions === Open to Export runs quarterly competitions encouraging businesses to complete their 'Export Action Plans'. 10 finalists are invited to a showcase final, with one winner being selected by a panel of expert judges to win a cash prize and further support prizes towards the implementation of their plans.
Open to Export has run eight UK-only competitions and one global competition - the 'Open to Export International Business Awards'. The Open to Export International Business Awards were run with the support of the World Trade Organisation and the International Chamber of Commerce. The Institute of Export & International Trade were named a 'Small Business Champion' by the WTO and ICC upon the completion of the competition.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wto.org/english/news_e/news18_e/sbc_04oct18_e.htm|title=WTO and ICC announce new Small Business Champion|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}}</ref>
The 10th Export Action Plan competition was opened in November 2019 and companies have until January 25th to enter.
==== Previous winners ==== Charles Farris<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://opentoexport.com/blog/export-action-plan-final-january-20th/|title=Export Action Plan Final - January 20th - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
Klick2Learn<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://opentoexport.com/blog/export-action-plan-case-study-klik2learn/|title=Export Action Plan Case Study: Klik2Learn - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
Lick Frozen Yogurt<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://opentoexport.com/blog/export-action-plan-case-study-lick-frozen-yogurt/|title=Export Action Plan Case Study: Lick Frozen Yogurt - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
First Chop Brewing Arm<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://opentoexport.com/blog/export-action-plan-food-drink-final-report-20-march/|title=Export Action Plan food and drink final report - 20 March - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
Genevieve Sweeney<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://opentoexport.com/blog/export-action-plan-east-england-report-22-march/|title=Export Action Plan East of England report – 22 March - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
four three six<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://opentoexport.com/blog/tech-meets-creative-final/|title=Export Action Plan: Tech meets Creative report – 30 March - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
The Great British Baby Company<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://opentoexport.com/blog/tech-meets-creative-final/|title=Export Action Plan: Tech meets Creative report – 30 March - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref>
Bubblebum (UK) Ltd<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.export.org.uk/news/404650/BubbleBum-UK-Limited-win-the-latest-Open-to-Export-Action-Plan-Competition.htm|title=The Institute of Export and International Trade|website=The Institute of Export and International Trade|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://natwest.contentlive.co.uk/content/bubblebum-a-story-of-exporting-success|title=BubbleBum: a story of exporting success|work=ContentLive|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en-gb}}</ref>
Dytech Limited (Zambia)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://opentoexport.com/blog/dytech-limited-win-the-open-to-export-international-business-awards/|title=Dytech Limited win the Open to Export International Business Awards - Open to Export|website=opentoexport.com|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-20}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wto.org/english/news_e/news18_e/sbc_04oct18_e.htm|title=WTO and ICC announce new Small Business Champion|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}}</ref> - international winner
== History == The site launched in beta in May 2012,<ref>{{cite web|first=Kevin|last=Coleman|title=Alliantus gets early invite from Open to Export|url=http://www.alliantus.com/mini-blog/alliantus-gets-early-invite-from-open-to-export/|publisher=Alliantus|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> during this time Open to Export limited the business sectors to technology, and the overseas markets to the US and India.
The site officially launched in October 2012.<ref>{{cite web|last=UKTI|title=Online service for small businesses launched|url=http://www.ukti.gov.uk/pt_pt/export/howwehelp/item/396500.html?null|publisher=UKTI|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Abigail|last=Van-West|title=UKTI launches free online service to boost international trade|url=http://www.growingbusiness.co.uk/ukti-launches-free-online-service-to-boost-international-trade.html|publisher=Growing Business|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref> At the time of launch Lord Green, then Minister of State for Trade and Investment, said: "Supporting more small and medium-sized enterprises to export is a key part of the government's plan for growth,"<ref>{{cite news|last=Telegraph|title=Better Future for Britain in the pipeline|url=http://jobs.telegraph.co.uk/article/4081309/better-future-for-britain-in-the-pipeline/|publisher=Telegraph.co.uk|accessdate=10 December 2012|location=London}}</ref> and went on to say "Half of the UK's exports, by value, already come from SMEs. Open to Export will provide practical assistance, advice and support to other businesses looking to make that crucial first step to sell into foreign markets." <ref>{{cite web|first=Rachel|last= Miller|title=Also in the news this week — 2nd November 2012|url=http://www.startupdonut.co.uk/news/startup/also-in-the-news-this-week-2nd-november-2012|publisher=Startup Donut|accessdate=10 December 2012}}</ref>
Ownership of Open to Export was taken on by the Institute of Export & International Trade in April 2017.
== See also == * [[Export]] * [[Trade]] * [[International trade]] * [[List of countries by exports]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [http://opentoexport.com Open to Export]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Magazine | logo = Outsource-logo.jpg | title = Outsource Magazine | image_file = | image_size = 149px | image_alt = Issue 25, November 2011 | image_caption = Outsource Magazine Issue 25, November 2011 | circulation = 11,361 (2012)<ref name=abc>[http://www.abc.org.uk/Certificates/18206089.pdf Outsource magazine]</ref> | frequency = Quarterly | language = English | category = [[Business]] | company = | editor = Jamie Liddell | editor_title = Editor | publisher = EMP Media Ltd | founded = 2005 | firstdate = | country = UK | based = | website = {{URL|http://outsourcemag.com/}} | issn = }} '''''Outsource''''' is a cross-channel publication and serves a senior management audience on thought leadership surrounding sourcing and shoring strategy. The magazine has an circulation verified by the [[Audit Bureau of Circulations (UK)|ABC]] during January and December 2012 of 11,361 (average per issue)<ref name=abc/> building on its 2011 audit making it the first magazine in the [[outsourcing]] sector to achieve this audited status <ref>[http://www.sourcewire.com/releases/rel_display.php?relid=66865 Outsource magazine becomes first in Outsourcing sector to achieve ABC audit | SourceWire<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
''Outsource'' is one of several of magazines published by EMP Media Ltd.<ref>[http://www.empgroup.co.uk/ EMP Group<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> It is a quarterly [[Business-to-business|B2B]] title that has been providing information to the [[outsourcing]] community since 2005 <ref>[http://outsourcemagazine.co.uk/ Outsource Magazine<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In February 2012 ''Outsource'' announced a partnership with the [[Association of Chartered Certified Accountants|ACCA (Association of Chartered Certified Accountants)]], the global professional body for accountants.<ref>[http://www.accaglobal.com/en/press/outsource-partnership.html Outsource Magazine & The Acca Announce An Exclusive Partnership | Acca Global<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.outsourcemagazine.co.uk/articles/item/4375-outsource-magazine-a-the-acca-announce-an-exclusive-partnership Outsource magazine and the ACCA announce an exclusive partnership<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://outsourcemag.com/ Official website]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=November 2015}} {{cleanup rewrite|date=March 2012}} }}
'''Perceptual mapping''' is a [[diagram]]matic technique used by asset [[marketing|marketers]] that attempts to visually display the perceptions of customers or potential customers. Typically the [[positioning (marketing)|position]] of a company's [[product (business)|product]], [[product line]], or [[brand]] is displayed relative to their competition.<ref name=":0">Mccarthy, E. J., Mcguiggan, I. R., Perreault, D. W., & Quester, G. P. (2007). ''Marketing: Creating and delivering value.'' Australia, Sydney: McGraw-Hill</ref> '''Perceptual maps''', also known as '''market maps''', usually have two dimensions but can be multi-dimensional; they can be used to identify gaps in the market and potential partners or merger targets as well as to clarify perceptual problems with a company's product.
== Uses == Perceptual mapping enables companies to better understand their customers: the who, why, where, how and what of their behaviour.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Drucker|first1=Peter F|title=The Practice of Management|date=2007|publisher=Routledge|location=London|isbn=0750685042|page=x Foreword|edition=2nd}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Brassington|first1=Frances|last2=Pettitt|first2=Stephen|title=Essentials of Marketing|date=2013|publisher=Pearson Education|location=Harlow|isbn=9780273728139|page=243|edition=3|language=English|chapter=6}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Jobber|first1=David|last2=Ellis-Chadwick|first2=Fiona|title=Principles and Practice of Marketing|date=2013|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=Maidenhead|isbn=9780077140007|page=290|edition=7|language=English|format=Paperback|chapter=8}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Feintzeig|first1=Rachel|title=Business News: Holiday Stress for Businesses|publisher=Wall Street Journal (Europe edition)|date=24 December 2015|page=B2|language=English}}</ref> <ref>{{cite news|last1=Jenkins|first1=Holman W Jr|title=The Broadband Future And Its Enemies|publisher=Wall Street Journal (Europe edition)|date=19 November 2015|location=New York|page=A.10|language=English}}</ref> If a business is perceived in a manner they find unsatisfactory, further research then identifies what can be done to change that. Perceptual mapping also allows businesses to see what consumers think of other brands, particularly their competitors. Regular uses of the maps can help track preferences, and see changes as they happen. Perceptual mapping can help define market segments, showing clusters of businesses differentiated by key aspects (such as higher class or number of restaurants). Within the clusters found in perceptual maps of entire industries, a business can classify potential partners or possible businesses to merge with, since the clustering of brands signifies the similarity in businesses, meaning they have corresponding attributes. It can also help identify gaps in a market where a new product or service could be introduced.<ref name=":0" /> Perceptual maps can also be used to help keep track of how a new product, such as a recently introduced smartphone, is being viewed in a specific market. It is important to see that the way a business is marketing its product is not only successful, but successful in a manner that aligns with the business’s overarching goal for positioning.
Some companies seem to have fallen out of favor with the public, such as Quicken Loans<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rudegeair|first1=Peter|title=At Quicken Loans, a Will to Do Battle|publisher=Wall Street Journal (Europe edition)|date=16 June 2015|page=25|language=English}}</ref> and VW.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Anonymous|title=A mucky business; The Volkswagen scandal|issue=416.8957|publisher=The Economist|date=26 September 2015|pages=23–25|language=English}}</ref> Perceptual mapping can help elicit the extent of the damage.
== Limitations == There are many limitations to perceptual mapping. The largest is the number of variables used. Traditionally, the map uses two variables and does not account for others. This assumption can hinder the reliability of results, as in some cases, it is not safe to assume that there are only two major factors influencing the decision of purchase for a consumer. For example, a graph may use quality of food and pricing, but not take into account other relevant variables such as the number of visits and locations. Also, there is often a blurred line between what a business can offer and what a consumer thinks the business can offer. This could be due to miscommunication, lack of knowledge, impact from social media, and so on. These untruths can influence the result, creating a slight bias in the statistics. Another limitation is data gathering. The data needed to form a perceptual map is usually obtained through surveys, and can be difficult to obtain. The range of behaviours that the map covers is also a constraint, as the limitation to two variables means that its application works mainly with purchase decisions made with little thought and effort, such as purchasing a beverage at a store or going to a fast food restaurant.
== Examples == Perceptual maps can have any number of dimensions but the most common is two dimensions. The first perceptual map below shows consumer perceptions of various [[automobile]]s on the two dimensions of sportiness/conservative and classy/affordable. This sample of consumers felt [[Porsche]] was the sportiest and classiest of the cars in the study (top right corner). They felt [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]] was most practical and conservative (bottom left corner).
[[Image:PerceptualMap1.png|center|frame|Perceptual map of competing products]]
Cars that are positioned close to each other are seen as similar on the relevant dimensions by the consumer. For example, consumers see Buick, Chrysler, and Oldsmobile as similar. They are close competitors and form a competitive grouping. A company considering the introduction of a new model will look for an area on the map free from competitors. Some perceptual maps use different-sized circles to indicate the sales volume or market share of the various competing products.
Displaying consumers’ perceptions of related products is only half the story. Many perceptual maps also display consumers’ ideal points. These points reflect ideal combinations of the two dimensions as seen by a consumer. The next diagram shows a study of consumers’ ideal points in the alcohol/spirits product space. Each dot represents one respondent's ideal combination of the two dimensions. Areas where there is a cluster of ideal points (such as A) indicate a [[market segment]]. Areas without ideal points are sometimes referred to as demand voids.
[[Image:PerceptualMap2.png|center|frame|Perceptual map of ideal points and clusters]]
A company considering introducing a new product will look for areas with a high density of ideal points. They will also look for areas without competitive rivals. This is best done by placing both the ideal points and the competing products on the same map.
Some maps plot ideal vectors instead of ideal points. The map below displays various aspirin products as seen on the dimensions of effectiveness and gentleness. It also shows two ideal vectors. The slope of the ideal vector indicates the ratio of the two dimensions preferred by those consumers within that segment. This study indicates that there is one segment that is more concerned with effectiveness than harshness, and another segment that is more interested in gentleness than strength.
[[Image:PerceptualMap3-new.png|center|frame|Perceptual map of competing products with ideal vectors]]
== Other types of mapping == === Spidergrams === Spidergrams are an alternative to perceptual mapping that similarly are visual marketing tools; however, spidergrams also request customers to rate attributes.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jobber|first1=David|last2=Ellis-Chadwick|first2=Fiona|title=Principles and Practice of Marketing|date=2013|publisher=McGraw-Hill|location=Maidenhead|isbn=9780077140007|page=291|edition=7|language=English|format=Paperback|chapter=8}}</ref>
=== Multidimensional perceptual maps === [[File:Multi-Dimensional Perceptual Map.gif|thumb|Example of a multi-dimensional perceptual map]] Traditional perceptual maps are built with two visual dimensions (X and Y axis). Multidimensional perceptual maps are built with more dimensions visualised as profile charts in small map regions, and then items are mapped to the regions by their similarity to the vectors that represent the region. A common technique to construct this kind of multidimensional perceptual maps is the [[self-organizing map]]. This helps pinpoint more variables, allowing for more in-depth research into what influences the consumer. This means that the perceptual map can be applied beyond low-involvement purchases, and also helps with identification of segments in a market.
=== Intuitive maps === Perceptual maps need not come from a detailed study. There are also intuitive maps (also called judgmental maps or consensus maps) that are created by marketers based on their understanding of their industry. These are limited by not being based on consumer data.
When detailed marketing research studies are done methodological problems can arise, but at least the information is coming directly from the consumer. An assortment of statistical procedures can be used to convert the raw data collected in a survey into a perceptual map. [[Preference regression (in marketing)|Preference regression]] will produce ideal vectors. [[Multi dimensional scaling (in marketing)|Multi dimensional scaling]] will produce either ideal points or competitor positions. [[Factor analysis]], [[discriminant analysis (in marketing)|discriminant analysis]], [[cluster analysis (in marketing)|cluster analysis]] and [[logit analysis (in marketing)|logit analysis]] can also be used. Some techniques are constructed from perceived differences between products, others from perceived similarities, and still others from [[Cross elasticity of demand|cross price elasticity of demand]] data from electronic scanners.
==Modern techniques==
Marketers can reveal shoppers' collective perceptual map with increasing precision and detail by aggregating and analysing their data; this is done, for example, in the smartphone and laptop industries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=Anthony JT|last2=Sun|first2=Chih-Yuan|last3=Yang|first3=Fu-Chen|last4=Chen|first4=Chao-Hung|last5=Wang|first5=Chun-Sheng|title=Mining perceptual maps from consumer reviews|journal=Decision Support Systems|date=2016|volume=82|issue=February|pages=12–25|doi=10.1016/j.dss.2015.11.002|publisher=Elsevier B.V.|language=English|issn=0167-9236}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zaribaf|first1=Mehdi|last2=Shameli|first2=Nora|title=Notebook Positioning by Perceptual Map and Laddering Method|journal=New Marketing Research Journal |date=Fall 2012 |volume=2 |issue=3|pages=121–134|publisher=University of Isfahan, Iran|language=Persian|issn=2228-7744}}</ref>
Furthermore, they can be used in non-commercial applications, such as identifying factors involved in dangerous driving.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vanlaar |first1=Ward |last2=Simpson |first2=Herb |last3=Robertson |first3=Robyn|title=A perceptual map for understanding concern about unsafe driving behaviours |journal=Accident Analysis and Prevention |date=2008 |volume=40 |issue=5 |pages=1667–1673|doi=10.1016/j.aap.2008.05.009|publisher=Elsevier B.V. |language=English |issn=0001-4575}}</ref>
==See also== * [[Diffusion of innovations]] * [[Discriminant analysis]] * [[Marketing research]] * [[Multidimensional scaling]] * [[Product life-cycle management (marketing)]] * [[Product management]]
== References == {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.perceptualmaps.com All About Perceptual Maps] * [http://www.perceptionmapping.com Organization Perception Mapping]

<ref>{{Plant Engineering|url=www.plantengineering.com}}</ref> {{Infobox Newspaper | image = [[Image:Plant engineering magazine cover.gif|Cover of Plant Engineering magazine]] | caption = | type = [[business]] [[magazine]] | format = | foundation = 1947 | ceased publication = | owners = CFE Media | editor = Bob Vavra | founder = | language = [[English language|English]] | political = | circulation = | headquarters = [[Downers Grove, Illinois]], USA | ISSN = 0032-082X | website = {{URL|https://www.plantengineering.com/}} }} '''''Plant Engineering''''' ({{ISSN|0032-082X}}) is a trade publication and web site owned by CFE Media. It covers the field of plant engineering and maintenance in both manufacturing and non-manufacturing industries. Since 1947, plant engineers, maintenance supervisors and manufacturing leaders have turned to ''Plant Engineering'' for the information they needed to run their plants smarter, safer, faster, and better. ''Plant Engineering's'' editors stay on top of the latest trends in manufacturing at every corner of the plant floor. The major content areas include electrical engineering, mechanical engineering, automation engineering and facility maintenance and plant management. Every November issue, ''Plant Engineering'' announces the [http://www.plantengineering.com/events-and-awards/product-of-the-year.html Product of the Year]. In the December issue, they announce the [http://www.plantengineering.com/events-and-awards/top-plant.html Top Plant], which honors the best manufacturing facilities.
In April 2010, former owner [[Reed Business Information]] announced the magazine would close. However later that month, ''[[Control Engineering (magazine)|Control Engineering]]'', ''[[Consulting-Specifying Engineer]]'' and ''Plant Engineering'' were acquired by a new company, CFE Media.
==References== [http://www.verifiedaudit.com/ Verified Audit]
==External links== *[https://www.plantengineering.com/ Plant Engineering website] *[https://www.cfemedia.com/ CFE Media website]
[[Category:1947 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:American business magazines]] [[Category:American monthly magazines]] [[Category:Engineering magazines]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1947]] [[Category:Magazines published in Illinois]] [[Category:Professional and trade magazines]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=January 2011}}
'''Rex L. Repass''' is a US-based public opinion and marketing research executive. He is president of Research America Inc., headquartered in Newtown Square, Pennsylvania with offices in Cincinnati, Ohio and throughout the US. Research America Inc. acquired R.L. Repass & Partners, Inc. (dba REPASS®) in 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/news/2016/11/30/fast-growing-cincinnati-firm-acquired.html|title=Growing Cincinnati Firm Acquired|last=|first=|date=|website=www.bizjournals.com|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref> In 2015 and 2016, Inc. magazine selected the REPASS firm as one of the fastest growing, privately held companies in the US.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.inc.com/profile/repass|title=REPASS: Number 2939 on the 2016 Inc. 5000|website=Inc.com|language=en|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref>
==Biography== Repass is a native of Charleston, West Virginia and a 1976 graduate of Marshall University in Huntington, West Virginia. He was a member of the Young Thundering Herd football team <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/sports/marshall_plane_crash/the_young_herd/young-herd-hopes-fans-stick-by-team/article_049ef245-cd43-5f54-800b-df602746a15b.html|title=Young Herd hopes fans stick by team|last=Herald-Dispatch|first=The|work=The Herald-Dispatch|access-date=2017-03-21|language=en}}</ref> in the early 1970s following the tragic plane crash <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/multimedia/photo_galleries/gallery-marshall-s-young-thundering-herd-victory-against-xavier-sept/article_79316c63-af72-505d-9e40-af046ae1ff3b.html|title=Gallery: Marshall's Young Thundering Herd victory against Xavier, Sept. 25, 1971|last=Herald-Dispatch|first=The|work=The Herald-Dispatch|access-date=2017-03-21|language=en}}</ref> that claimed the lives of 75 players, coaches, athletic administrators, and team boosters. In 1994, Repass was elected to Marshall's W. Page Pitt School of Journalism & Mass Communications Hall of Fame for his contribution to media and public opinion research.
In 1977, Repass received a master of science degree in communications from the University of Tennessee-Knoxville, with a special emphasis in public opinion and advertising research.
In 1980, Repass developed The West Virginia Poll for the [[Charleston Daily Mail]], WSAZ Television and The [[Associated Press]].<ref name="wvpoll">[http://www.wcwv.org/newsletter_archives/2006_newsletters/newsletter_vol_3_num_5_may01_2006.pdf Wellness Council of West Virginia], accessed November 3, 2010</ref> The West Virginia Poll was the first media sponsored scientific measurement of [[public opinion]] in West Virginia. The West Virginia Poll continues to this day and is sponsored <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wvmetronews.com/2014/08/29/wv-poll-shows-capito-up-17/|title=WV Poll shows Capito up 17|date=2014-08-29|website=WV MetroNews|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref> by the [[West Virginia MetroNews|MetroNews Radio Network]].
In 1988, Repass moved his research practice from Charleston, West Virginia to MarketVision Research Inc. in Cincinnati, Ohio where he was president of the organization.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.enquirer.com/editions/2000/06/06/fin_blue_ash_firm_leads.html|title=Blue Ash firm leads Internet study|website=www.enquirer.com|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref> In 2001, he sold his interest in MarketVision and formed what became R.L. Repass & Partners Inc.
Today Repass and the Research America Inc. organization provide survey research and strategic consulting services to [[Fortune 500]] corporations,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.repassinc.com/our-work|title=REPASS Research and Strategy|last=|first=|date=|website=REPASS, Inc.|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-21}}</ref> state and national trade [[Trade association|associations]], and governmental agencies. He has also directed [[Public Opinion Research|public opinion]] and [[market research]] for media clients including [[The Arizona Republic]], The Sunday Examiner-Chronicle in San Francisco, [[Poynter Institute|The Poynter Institute]] for Media Studies, [[Thomson Reuters]] and more than 40 newspapers and media companies in the United States and Canada.
Repass is a member of the [[American Association for Public Opinion Research]].
==See also== * [[Quantitative marketing research]] * [[Qualitative marketing research]] * [[Brand Equity]] * [[Advertising Research]] * [[Observational techniques]] * [[Online research communities]]
==Articles== * [http://cincinnati.bizjournals.com/cincinnati/stories/2007/08/06/smallb3.html?surround=etf Cincinnati Business Courier] * [http://repasspartners.com/news/2007-04-25.html Look Good...Feel Better] * [http://repasspartners.com/news/2007-04-20.html Charleston Gazette] * [http://repasspartners.com/news/2006-10-16.html Convenience Store News] * [https://archive.is/20131003083717/http://www.nationaljournal.com/member/daily/coal-politics-put-rockefeller-at-risk-20120912 National Journal Daily, ''Coal Politics Put Rockefeller at Risk'']
==References== {{Reflist|2}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Repass, Rex}} [[Category:University of Tennessee alumni]] [[Category:Marshall University alumni]] [[Category:Marshall Thundering Herd football players]] [[Category:Market researchers]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox State Representative | name=Richard L. "Dick" Barclay |image = | office=[[Arkansas House of Representatives|Arkansas State Representative
for Benton County]] | party=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | term_start=1976 | term_end=1992 | preceded= | succeeded= | birth_date={{birth date and age|1937|6|5}} | birth_place=[[Oberlin, Kansas|Oberlin]], [[Decatur County, Kansas|Decatur County]]
[[Kansas]], United States | residence=[[Rogers, Arkansas|Rogers]], [[Benton County, Arkansas|Benton County]]
[[Arkansas]] | religion= | occupation=[[Certified Public Accountant]] | spouse=Jan K. Barclay | children= | footnotes= }} '''Richard L. "Dick" Barclay''' (born June 5, 1937) is a [[Certified Public Accountant]] in [[Rogers, Arkansas|Rogers]], a city in [[Benton County, Arkansas|Benton County]] in the northwestern corner of [[Arkansas]], [[United States]], who was a [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] member of the [[Arkansas House of Representatives]] from December 31, 1976 to December 31, 1992. He was also the director of the Arkansas Department of Finance and Administration under Republican [[governor of Arkansas|Governor]] [[Mike Huckabee|Michael Dale "Mike" Huckabee]]. In 1992, he lost a [[primary election]] for the [[United States House of Representatives]] to then fellow State Representative [[Tim Hutchinson]] of [[Bentonville, Arkansas|Bentonville]], the seat of government of Benton County. Barclay was born in [[Oberlin, Kansas|Oberlin]] in [[Decatur County, Kansas|Decatur County]] in northwestern [[Kansas]]. He began work as an accountant in 1961 and is a partner in the firm Beall, Barclay, and Company. He is a member of the Arkansas Society of Certified Public Accountants and of the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants. He is a director of the Federal Savings Bank in Rogers and United Bank. He is a former vice president of the Arkansas State [[Chamber of Commerce]]. He is also a member of the [[board of directors]] of the Brokers National Life Assurance Company. He is one of sixteen commissioners of the Arkansas Economic Development Commission. In 2000, Barclay was elected president of the Arkansas Society of CPAs. That same year, he was named "Arkansas Business Person of the Year" by [[Beta Gamma Sigma]] of [[Sam Walton]] College of the [[University of Arkansas]] in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas|Fayetteville]]. [[Mack McLarty]], a former chief of staff to [[U.S. President]] [[Bill Clinton]], won this honor in 2007. Barclay was [[executive director]] of Legislative Affairs and Budget until tapped by Huckabee in 1999 to head Finance and Administration. He left state employment in the spring of 2002 to return to his business in Rogers and was succeeded by Richard A. Weiss, who left the Arkansas Department of Environmental Quality to take the Finance and Administration position. Barclay did not seek a ninth two-year term in the Arkansas House in 1992. Instead, he ran for the Third Congressional District seat opened by the retirement of longtime Republican [[incumbent]] [[John Paul Hammerschmidt]]. However, he lost the [[Republican Party (United States)|GOP]] nomination to Tim Hutchinson, who would serve in the U.S. House from 1993 to 1997 and in the [[United States Senate]] from 1997 to 2003. In 2003, Barclay served as chairman of the Benton County Republican Party. He is married to Jan K. Barclay. He is a member of the [[Disciples of Christ]].{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} {{Portalbar|Biography|Kansas|Arkansas|Politics|Business and Economics|Christianity}} ==References== *http://www.secinfo.com/dN3s6.78.htm *http://edgar.secdatabase.com/44/75764106000003/filing-main *http://bgs.waltoncollege.uark.edu/default.asp?show=honorees *https://securewww.bnlac.com/bnlwww/bnlac/management.asp *http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/barc-barhite.html *http://www.waltoncollege.uark.edu/acct/newsletters/99fall.pdf http://www.bipac.org/detail.asp?id=397 *http://www.arkansas.gov/dfa/income_tax/quarterly/archives/quarterly-vol_VIII-3.pdf *http://www.manta.com/comsite5/bin/pddnb_company.pl?pdlanding=1&referid=3550&id=dz3h8t *http://www.1800arkansas.com/info/index.cfm?page=commission {{DEFAULTSORT:Barclay, Richard L}} [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Oberlin, Kansas]] [[Category:People from Rogers, Arkansas]] [[Category:Members of the Arkansas House of Representatives]] [[Category:Arkansas Republicans]] [[Category:American accountants]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox person | name = Samir Mane | image = | imagesize = | birth_date = 24 December 1967 | birth_place = [[Korçë]], [[Albania]] | known_for = Balfin Group
Mane TCI
QTU
[[Tirana East Gate]]
[[Tirana logistic park|Tirana Logistic Park]] | nationality = {{flagicon|Albania}} [[Albania]] | spouse = | children = 4 }} '''Samir Mane''' is the richest [[Albanian people|Albanian]] entrepreneur. He is president and owner of [http://balfin.al/ BALFIN Group], which is the largest private investment groups in Albania and South-east Europe. The Group`s investment portfolio embraces activities of real estate development, retail sales, commercial and industrial space management\ services, mining and metallurgy industry, customer financing, est. Actually part of BALFIN Group are more than 18 companies; geographically the Group is present in 7 countries, employing more than 3,000 people. ==Biography== Mane was born in the southern Albanian city of [[Korça]] on 24 December 1967. He was a student of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20131021161154/http://www.upt.al/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=50&Itemid=29&lang=en Faculty of Geology and Mining at Tirana University] when the communist system in Albania collapsed. In this new social, economical and political situation he emigrated in [[Austria]] looking for a better life. Mane started working as a translator, helping himself to create contacts with the business world too. Whilst living in [[Austria]] in 1993, he spotted the opportunity to start business with electronic products and home appliances in Albania. In 2008 he was included in the ''[[Financial Times]]'' top four "people to watch in business" in Albania.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/7e2cad2a-fa18-11dc-9b7c-000077b07658.html#axzz3O9TS6WZx |title=People to watch in business |work=Financial Times |date=2008-03-27 |accessdate=2012-08-08}} [http://mapo.al/2013/11/14/samir-mane-komod-ne-marredheniet-shtetin-ja-investimet-tona-ne-bulqize/comment-page-1/#comment-80051 Mane's net worth is estimated to be around 700 million euros. ==Alba Trade and Neptun== The beginnings of Mane's business activities started in 1993 in Vienna, where Mane founded [http://balfin.al/page.php?m=albatrade Alba Trade]. Having started with the trade of electronic devices, soon the Balfin Group, created by Mane managed to create the largest network of electronics stores in Albania, Neptun and then extending the network in the neighboring countries as well. [http://www.neptun.al Neptun]'s chain of stores was positioned from the beginning in 1993 as the main electronics player in the Albanian market supplying the demand with the best brands and latest technology. Today this business created by Mane counts 28 stores in Albania and more than 27 in Kosova, Montenegro, Macedonia and Serbia.http://www.oranews.tv/vendi/neptun-me-dyqan-te-ri-tek-cristal-center-oferta-per-te-gjithe-te-interesuarit/ ==Mane TCI== Since 2002 Balfin Group is present in development and real estate management projects. Through the company [http://www.manetci.com.al/new/ Mane TCI] it has realized industrial and residential facilities of the highest standards in Albania such as [http://rollinghills.al/ Rolling Hills], Ambasador 1, 2, 3, etc, or the well known shopping centers such as TEG or QTU. ==QTU, Euromax, Fashion Group== In 2005, it was inaugurated the first shopping center in Albania, [http://www.qtu.al Qendra Tregtare Univers] (Universe Trade Center). This was a very ambitious project of Mane's for the time and revolutionized the purchasing way of the Albanian customers. Even today [http://www.qtu.al/historiku QTU] is still one of the most popular and successful shopping centers in Albania. The year 2005 marked the establishment of the first Albanian chain of supermarkets, Euromax. In a very short time Euromax managed to turn into the largest network of supermarkets in Albania offering quality with the best prices. [http://balfin.al/struktura-e-grupit/tregtia-me-pakice/fashion-group/ Fashion Group] was established in 2005 to bring in Albania the most popular brands of clothing, offering the latest collections for all Brands of Fashion Group are: Mango, Goldenpoint, Calliope, Geox, Parfois, Okaidi, Prenatal, Terranova, Springfield, Carpisa and Etam. ==TEG== In 2011 Balfin Group completed another important project, [http://teg.al/ Tirana East Gate]. With an investment of €54 million, it was constructed the most modern and the largest shopping center in Albania with over 90'000 m2. ==Skopje City Mall, Honorary Consul of Thailand, Tirana Logistic Park== In October 2012 Balfin Group concluded one of the most important investments of the group abroad, [http://www.skopjecitymall.mk/ Skopje City Mall]. This €68 million project was developed in cooperation with the participation of [http://www.ebrd.com/ international partners]. In March 2012 he was named the [[honorary consul]] of [[Thailand]] at the opening ceremony of the new [[consulate]].{{cite web|url=http://www.balkanweb.com/shqiperi/2685/zamir-mane-konsull-nderi-i-tajlandes-ne-shqiperi-85272.html |title=Zamir Mane, konsull nderi i Tajlandës në Shqipëri |publisher=Balkanweb.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-08}} Again during 2012 Mane with Balfin Group undertook a bold project yet again, building a logistic park, which is another groundbreaking innovation for the Albanian market. [http://tlp.al/ [[Tirana logistic park|Tirana Logistic Park]]] is designed to provide services not only to Albanian businesses, but also the foreign. [https://web.archive.org/web/20131021163759/http://www.pie-mag.com/articles/4037/albania-s-balfin-starts-tirana-logistics-park-in-capital/ This investment] will be developed in phases and the first phase was finalized in October 2013. The total investment costs are planned to be about €44 million. ==[[AlbChrome]]== In 2013 Balfin Group took a very important step to diversify the portfolio of activities in the mineral industry by acquiring 100% of the shares of [http://albchrome.al/ ACR Holding], the largest company of extraction, enrichment and processing of chrome in Albania. Mane has created the most successful Group in Albania with more than 4,000 employees. == Green Coast == In 2015, Mane started building, Green Coast, which is among the most luxurious compounds among the Albanian Coast, containing ten types of buildings, from elite villas to apartments, including a 5 star hotel. This project is taken on by [http://www.manetci.com.al/new/ Mane TCI] . == Spar and Interspar == In 2016 Mane and Balfin Group turned all the Carrefour in Albania, into Spars and Interspars. This is a Dutch brand, founded on 1932 and is currently present in more than 42 countries around the world. ==Controversy== Mane has been subject to strong controversy from Albanian activists, due to his strong political connections, which have allowed him to profit massively in different areas of business. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mane, Samir}} [[Category:Albanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1967 births]] [[Category:People from Korçë]]

Added some information to the in markets section. Also added a sentence to in households section.
revision.text:
{{About||the Daniel Lee Chee Hun album|Sharing (album)|other uses|Share (disambiguation){{!}}Share}} [[File:Viola and Mina share food.jpg|thumb|Sharing food]] [[File:215-365 - This Strawberrybananna smoothie is better than the Wildberry (- (4760692715).jpg|thumb|Sharing drink]] [[File:Pond Sliders at Smithsonian National Zoological Park in Washington.jpg|thumb|Reptiles sharing space]] '''Sharing''' is the joint use of a resource or space. In its narrow sense, it refers to joint or alternating use of inherently finite goods, such as a common [[pasture]] or a shared residence. It is also the process of dividing and distributing. Apart from obvious instances, which we can observe in human activity, we can also find many examples of this happening in nature. When an organism takes in nutrition or oxygen for instance, its internal organs are designed to divide and distribute the energy taken in, to supply parts of its body that need it. Flowers divide and distribute their seeds. In a broader sense, it can also include free granting of use rights to goods that can be treated as [[Rivalry (economics)|nonrival goods]], such as information. Still more loosely, "sharing" can actually mean giving something as an outright gift: for example, to "share" one's food really means to give some of it as a gift. Sharing is a basic component of human interaction, and is responsible for strengthening social ties and ensuring a person’s well-being.{{cite web|last=Poquérusse|first=Jessie|title=The Neuroscience of Sharing|url=https://www.uniiverse.com/neuroscience|accessdate=16 August 2012}} ==In a market== Market sharing occurs when competitors agree to divide or allocate customers, suppliers or territories among themselves rather than allowing competitive market forces to work.{{Cite news|url=https://www.accc.gov.au/business/anti-competitive-behaviour/cartels/market-sharing#market-sharing|title=Market sharing|last=Commission|first=Australian Competition and Consumer|date=2013-01-09|work=Australian Competition and Consumer Commission|access-date=2018-11-21|language=en}} Market sharing can include: * allocating customers by geographic area * dividing contracts by value within an area Also agreeing not to: * compete for established customers * produce each other’s products or services * expand into a competitor’s market Market sharing is generally an illegal practice as it violates anti-trust laws and the basic principles of the free market. Market sharing mainly occur in the form of cartels like the [[Guadalajara_Cartel|Guadalajara Cartel]], which was the first Mexican drug cartel to consolidate the production and supply of illegal marijuana into a single organization. Sharing in a market may also refer to the temporary or permanent transfer of information and other physical as well as intellectual property, but this is generally accompanied by the exchange of money.{{expand section|date=November 2018}} ==In households== [[File:Green sharing (1).jpg|thumb|Plant sharing]] Resource sharing - called kaláka in Hungarian - is an old tradition in Hungary. Young couples had to build their house after marriage. Marriage itself was called házasodás in Hungarian (en: becoming the owner of a house). When doing so the whole community, relatives and acquaintances helped the young couple with work, knowledge and even money. At pigsticking, all members of the community got their shares too. Superfluous plants were freely distributed for neighbours in the season. In most cultures, members of the same household tend to pool their resources. ==In computer and Internet culture== {{main|Image sharing|File sharing}} {{expand section|date=January 2017}} [[File sharing]] is the practice of distributing or providing access to digitally stored information, such as computer programs, multi-media (audio, video), documents, or electronic books. It may be implemented through a variety of ways. Storage, transmission, and distribution models are common methods of file sharing incorporate manual sharing using [[removable media]], centralized computer file server installations on [[computer network]]s, [[World Wide Web]]-based [[hyperlink]]ed documents, and the use of distributed [[peer-to-peer networking]] (see [[peer-to-peer file sharing]]). Sharing is a key feature in the developing field of [[free software]] and [[open source software]], with implications for economics. This is leading to a need to review [[licensing]], [[patents]] and [[copyright]], and to [[controversy]] in these areas, as well as new approaches like [[Creative Commons]] and the [[GNU General Public License|GPL]]. Furthermore, sharing is a key feature of [[Internet culture]] in which images, videos, links, knowledge and other content are shared on [[Web 2.0]]-platforms such as [[reddit]].[http://nms.sagepub.com/content/15/2/167 John, Nicholas A. (2013) Sharing and Web 2.0: The emergence of a keyword. New Media & Society, March 2013 vol. 15 no. 2 167-182]{{cite book|last1=Herman|first1=Andrew|last2=Hadlaw|first2=Jan|last3=Swiss|first3=Thom|title=Theories of the Mobile Internet: Materialities and Imaginaries|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317911128|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=BFucBQAAQBAJ&pg=PA145|accessdate=4 April 2017|language=en}} ==In computer science== In [[computer science]], the issue of handling [[shared resource]]s figures prominently. For example, [[time-sharing]] is an approach to [[interactive computing]] in which a single [[computer]] is used to provide apparently simultaneous interactive general-purpose computing to multiple users by sharing processor time. Sharing of resources between [[Process (computer science)|processes]] and [[Thread (computer science)|threads]] is the source of most of the difficulties of [[concurrent programming]]. The word "sharing" is also used in some [[functional programming]] communities to refer specifically to sharing of memory between different data items to save space, otherwise known as [[hash consing]]. {{see also|Call by sharing|Aliasing (computing)|Concurrency control|File locking}} ==In religions== ===Information and knowledge=== * The KJV Bible, [[s:Bible (King James)/1 Corinthians#Chapter 13|1 Corinthians 13:2]] says that '''having all the knowledge in the world is useless, without the desire for charity (sharing).''' * The Douay-Rheims Bible, [http://drbo.org/x/d?b=drb&bk=57&ch=1&l=9#x Philippians 1:9] says "'''And this I pray, that your charity may more and more abound in knowledge, and in all understanding'''". * In editions of the Christian Bible, [[s:Bible (American Standard)/Hosea#4|Hosea 4:6]] says that '''obstruction of the flow of knowledge could be the destruction of mankind.''' * '''Vidya Daan''' ({{lang|sa|विद्या दान}}) translated as '''Knowledge Charity''', a concept in [[Dāna|Daan]], is a [[Niyama|tenet]] of all [[Indian religions|Dharmic]] religions that also values the sharing of Knowledge.[http://www.sanskrit.us/vidya.html Sanskrit slokas about Vidya][http://vidyadaan.in/about/ Vidya Daan: about] *'''Gyan yoga''', '''[[Jnana yoga]]''' ({{lang|sa|ज्ञान योग}}) translated as '''Wisdom Exercise''' or '''Knowledge Path''', is the '''sacred search for True Knowledge''', in all Dharmic religions. * In Hinduism, [[Vidya|Right Knowledge]] is a form of God, and anything that Knowledge is written on or recorded on is considered sacred, to be protected from obscurity:
{{lang|sa|अपूर्व: कोपि कोशोयं विद्यते तव भारति ।
व्ययतो वॄद्धिम् आयाति क्षयम् आयाति संचयात् ॥}}
:* Translation: '''Oh Goddess [[Saraswati]], your treasure of knowledge ([[Vidya]]) is indeed very amazing! If used (shared) it grows and if unused (obscured) it shrinks!''' *In Islam, [[Muhammad]] said: "'''Wisdom is the lost property of the faithful; wherever he finds it he has the right to take it'''"Sunan Tirmidhi Tradition:4159, Sunan Ibn Majah Tradition:9784, Ibid Tradition:9785, Mishkat al-Masabih Tradition:216 :Muhammad also said: "'''Whoever is asked about a knowledge that he knows about and then hides it and keeps it away, he will be bridled on the day of judgement with a bridle of fire.'''"Related by Ahmad, Abu Dawud and Al-Tirmidhi ==See also== {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| *[[Collaborative consumption]] *[[Common ownership]] *[[Generosity]] *[[Knowledge sharing]] *[[Participatory culture]] *[[Sharing economy]] *[[Tragedy of the commons]] *[[The Apple War (book)|''The Apple War'']] *[[Usufruct]] }} ==References== * Yochai Benkler, Sharing Nicely: On Shareable Goods and the Emergence of Sharing as a Modality of Economic Production, ''Yale Law Journal'', Vol. 114, 273-358 ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110928101312/http://www.yalelawjournal.org/pdf/114-2/Benkler_114-2.pdf PDF]) * Bruce Perens (2005). [https://web.archive.org/web/20051102235831/http://perens.com/Articles/Economic.html “The Emerging Economic Paradigm of Open Source”]. Retrieved October 25, 2005. * Kaláka in http://mek.niif.hu/02100/02115/html/2-1770.html *Market sharing, https://www.accc.gov.au/business/anti-competitive-behaviour/cartels/market-sharing#market-sharing ==Footnotes== ==External links== {{Wiktionary}} {{wikiquote}} *{{Commons category-inline}} * [http://www.digital-development-debates.org/issue-17-sharing.html Sharing] Issue by online magazine Digital Development Debates, 2016. [[Category:Sharing| ]] [[Category:Social economy]] [[Category:Production economics]]

'''Sigma''' (Science in General Management) was a [[limited company]] established by [[Henry Novy]], [[Stafford Beer]] and [[Roger Eddison]] in 1961. It sold [[operational research]] OR in the [[United Kingdom]] and overseas. Beer was responsible for the cybernetic models of organisation and corporate planning which were the firm's specially. Eddison was the Operations Director.
The consultancy arose following discussions between the Société d’Économie et de Mathématiques Appliquées (SEMA) and Martech Consultants Limited. Novy, who ran Maretch, was given the job of selecting the people to run the company, inviting several OR practitioners to come to Paris for an interview. After he selected Beer, Beer only agreed if Eddison would also join him. This was arranged and the company was launched with a reception at the [[Connaught Hotel]] in October 1961.<ref name="Beer">{{cite journal |last1=Beer |first1=Stafford |title=Roger Tatham Eddison: an appreciation |journal=Journal of the Operational Research Society |date=August 2000 |volume=51 |issue=8 |pages=1004–1007 |doi=10.1057/palgrave.jors.2600989 |url=https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1057/palgrave.jors.2600989 |accessdate=29 September 2018 |language=en |issn=0160-5682}}</ref>
Over the next five years Sigma developed into a substantial organisation providing services to several leading companies across the UK as well as for six government departments. It also took on contracts in the United States and several developing countries. Amongst the diverse areas it worked in were energy, for the [[Gas Council]], transportation, for [[British Rail]] and the [[Port of London Authority]], shipbuilding, for the [[Geddes Committee]], education for [[Yugoslavia]], tourism, for [[Israel]], nationalised industry in South America, and distribution for a variety of industrial firms.<ref name="GCF">{{cite web|last1=Cabezas Fuentealba|first1=Guido|title=Beer|url=http://www.oocities.org/gicabezas/Beer.html|website=www.oocities.org|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref>
Sigma, Martech, and Proplan were amalgamated to form what afterwards became the Metra Consulting Group in the United Kingdom.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Operations research]]

'''Small Rockets''' was a British computer game developer located in Guildford, England. The company was founded in October 2000 and created and sold PC games online.
== History == Small Rockets was born from the ashes of [[Fiendish Games]], a department of [[Criterion Games]] (also known as Criterion Software), that was started to test the waters for delivering games online rather than through traditional retail channels. When Fiendish Games was shut down, the then head of department Jonathan Small set up Small Rockets to continue where Fiendish Games had left off. The company licensed the games created by Fiendish Games from Criterion, and most of the Fiendish Games employees moved with Jonathan to the new company.
In addition to its commercial games Small Rockets also produced a bespoke 'one off' game called 'HP Spy Academy' for a [[Hewlett-Packard|HP]] exhibition at 'Stuff Live' in 2002.
Work continued on several more PC titles and a Game Boy Advance title until most of the employees had to be let go, largely for financial reasons, in 2003.
Due to the increasing costs of running a UK-registered limited-liability company from the US, the decision was made in 2012 to shut the company down. The Small Rockets website displayed a formal notice of the shutdown from early July 2012, at which point the site's shop was also disabled. Full shutdown of the Small Rockets servers (including the website itself) occurred in late August 2012. Jonathan has stated that he hopes to continue Small Rockets' ''Red Ace'' franchise.
== Small Rockets Games == === Games originally written as part of Fiendish Games === * [[Natural Fawn Killers]] (abbreviated NFK) * [[Tower of the Ancients]] * [[Master of the Skies: The Red Ace]] (previously known as [[Hunt for the Red Baron]]) * [[Art is Dead]] * [[Hot Chix 'n' Gear Stix]] * [[Hot Chix 'n' Gear Stix 2]] * [[Small Rockets Poker]] * [[Small Rockets Mah Jongg]] * [[Small Rockets Backgammon]] * [[MAD: Global Thermonuclear Warfare]]
=== Games released wholly by Small Rockets ===
* [[NFK: Santa's Gone Postal]] * [[Star Monkey]] * [[Ultra Assault]] * [[Red Ace Squadron]] * [[Small Rockets Assimilation|Assimilation]] * Sean Murray Wakeboarding (GBA) * Sinbad (PC)
==References== <references/>
==External links== * www.smallrockets.com The Small Rockets website (now dead) *[http://www.mobygames.com/company/small-rockets Small Rockets] entry at [[MobyGames]]
[[Category:Video game development companies]] [[Category:Defunct companies]] [[Category:Video game companies of the United Kingdom]]
{{UK-videogame-company-stub}}

{{Infobox NRHP | name =St. James' Roman Catholic Church | nrhp_type = nrhp | image =St-james-church.jpg | image_size = 325px | caption = (2007) | location = 32 James Street
[[Manhattan]], [[New York City]] | coordinates = {{coord|40|42|44|N|73|59|55|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Lower Manhattan | built = 1835-37 | architect = attributed to [[Minard Lafever]] | architecture =[[Greek Revival architecture|Greek Revival]] | mpsub = | added = July 24, 1972 | governing_body = Private | refnum = 72000884{{NRISref|2009a}} | designated_other2_name = NYC Landmark | designated_other2_date = January 18, 1966 | designated_other2_abbr = NYCL | designated_other2_link = New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission | designated_other2_color = #ffe978 }} '''St. James' Roman Catholic Church''' is located at 32 James Street between St. James Place and Madison Street in the [[Two Bridges, Manhattan|Two Bridges]] neighborhood of [[Lower Manhattan]], [[New York City]].{{cite aia5}}, p.89 It is the second oldest Roman Catholic building in the city, built in 1835-37 of [[fieldstone]], with a pair of [[Doric order|Doric]] columns flanking the entrance.{{cite nycland}}, p.45 While the [[Neo-classical architecture|neo-Classical]] church is modeled on the published designs by [[Minard Lefever]], and is sometimes attributed to him, there is no hard evidence of this being true.{{cite fromatoz}}, p.210-11 The building was once topped by a domed [[cupola]]. ==History== The parish was established by [[John Dubois|Bishop John Dubois]] in order to relieve the overcrowding at [[St. Peter Catholic Church (Manhattan)|St. Peter's]] on Barclay Street. He purchased an Episcopal church building on Ann Street, retaining the name of Christ Church, and asked Father [[Félix Varela]] to organize a congregation. Fr. Varela also established a free school. In October 1833, it was discovered that nearby excavation had rendered Christ Church unsound. Pending the completion of a new building on James Street, premises were rented at 33 Ann Street. However, some members of the congregation finding this too far uptown, instead purchased the Reformed Presbyterian church on Chambers Street. This would become the parish of the [[Church of the Transfiguration, Roman Catholic (Manhattan)|Transfiguration]], with Fr. Varela as the first pastor.[https://books.google.com/books?id=KL4YAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA396#v=onepage&q&f=false Lafort, Remigius. ''The Catholic Church in the United States of America: Undertaken to Celebrate the Golden Jubilee of His Holiness, Pope Pius X'', Catholic editing Company, 1914, p. 336]{{PD-notice}} The first Mass was said in the basement of the James St. church on September 18, 1836. The following January it was dedicated under the invocation of St. James the Apostle, by Bishop Dubois. [[Andrew Byrne]] was appointed rector. Byrne was succeeded in 1842 by Rev. John Maginnis, who was in turn followed by Rev. John N. Smith. In 1848 Fr. Smith succumbed to "[[Typhus|ship fever]]" contracted when administering last rites to Father Murphy of Staten Island, who had contracted the illness while tending recently arrived immigrants. [[Alfred E. Smith]] served as an [[altar boy]] at this church when he was a student at its [[Catholic school|parochial school]], the former [[St. James Elementary School (New York)|St. James Elementary School]], located across the street. The church was ordered to be closed by New York City officials in 1983, because of the danger of its roof collapsing. It was scheduled to be torn down in 1986, but was saved by the efforts of the community, especially the [[Ancient Order of Hibernians]], the first branch of which was organized in the church in 1836. The building suffered significant damage in a fire on January 11, 2011.Cunningham, Jennifer H. and Paddock, Barry. "Firefighters Save Historic Manhattan Church," ''[[New York Daily News]]'' (January 11, 2011) In 2007, St. James Parish merged with the nearby Parish of St. Joseph. The combined Parish of St. Joseph/St. James was merged again with the Church of the Transfiguration in 2015. ===Pastors=== {{columns list|colwidth=30em| * Fr. Andrew Byrne, 1837-1842 * Fr. John Maginnis, 1842 * Fr. John N. Smith, 1842-1848 * Fr. Patrick McKenna, 1848-1858 * Fr. Thomas Martin O.P. 1858-1859 * Fr. James Brennan, 1859-1865 * Fr. Felix Farrelly, 1865-1880 * Fr. John J. Kean, 1880-1901 * Fr. James B. Curry, 1901-? }} ==See also== *[[List of New York City Landmarks]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in New York County, New York]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{commonscat-inline|St. James' Roman Catholic Church (Manhattan)}} {{New York City Historic Sites|state=collapsed}} {{National Register of Historic Places in New York|state=collapsed}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saint James' Church, New York City}} [[Category:Roman Catholic churches in Manhattan]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches completed in 1837]] [[Category:19th-century Roman Catholic church buildings in the United States]] [[Category:Properties of religious function on the National Register of Historic Places in Manhattan]] [[Category:Hibernian buildings]] [[Category:Landmarks in Manhattan]] [[Category:Irish-American culture in New York City]] [[Category:Greek Revival architecture in New York City]] [[Category:Greek Revival church buildings in New York City]] [[Category:Lower Manhattan]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches on the National Register of Historic Places in New York (state)]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox church |name = St. John's Cathedral
256 East Church Street
[[Jacksonville, Florida]] |image = StJohnsCathedralJaxInside.PNG |dedication = St. [[John the Evangelist]] |denomination = [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal]] |churchmanship = |parish = |deanery = |archdeaconry = |diocese = [[Episcopal Diocese of Florida|Florida]]
The Rt. Rev. [[Samuel Johnson Howard]], Bishop |province = [[Province 4 of the Episcopal Church in the United States of America|IV]] |dean = The Very Rev. [[Kate Moorehead]] |honpriest = |director = |organist = Timothy Tuller |warden = Susan Corey |website =[http://www.jaxcathedral.org/ St. John’s Cathedral, Jacksonville website] }} '''St. John's Cathedral''' is a [[cathedral]] of the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] in [[Jacksonville, Florida]], U.S. One of the oldest congregations in Jacksonville, it became the [[cathedra|seat]] of the Bishop of the [[Episcopal Diocese of Florida]] in 1951.[http://www.cardcow.com/64985/st-johns-episcopal-cathedral-jacksonville-us-state-town-views-florida-jacksonville/#img Cardcow.com: postcard of St. John's Episcopal Cathedral with 1957 postmark] The current building dates to 1906. ==History== [[Image:StJohnsCathedralJaxLogo.PNG|left|100px|Cathedral Shield]] The congregation was founded in 1834 as St. John's Parish. It is one of the seven original parishes dating to the reception of the Diocese of Florida into the Episcopal General Convention in 1838. According to the cornerstone for the present Cathedral, the first St. Johns Church was built in 1842 and burned in 1862 during the American Civil War. In the early 1870s, [[Edward Tuckerman Potter]] designed a new St. Johns and initial construction began in 1873. The church was completed and dedicated in 1877. This building burned in the [[Great Fire of 1901]], which destroyed most of [[Downtown Jacksonville]], and the next year a new church was designed by [[Howard Nott Potter]] of the firm Snelling and Potter. St. John's Cathedral was completed and consecrated in 1906.Nemmers, John R.: [http://web.uflib.ufl.edu/spec/manuscript/guides/potter.htm "A Guide to the Edward T. Potter Architectural Drawings"] University of Florida, Smathers Libraries St. John's is the only cathedral in Jacksonville.Cushman, Joseph D., Jr., ''A Goodly Heritage: The Episcopal Church in Florida, 1821-1892'', Gainesville: University of Florida Press (1965) Inside the building is cavernous; built in the [[Gothic Revival]] architectural style, stained-glass windows line the walls. In 1983, Advent Glass Works restored or repaired all stained glass in the Cathedral, the Cloister and the Cummings Chapel.[http://www.adventglassworks.com/customers.html Advent Glass Works: client project-St. John's Cathedral] ==School== The St. John's Cathedral School is sponsored by the Cathedral and Diocese and includes infants to Pre-K 4. It also receives funding from the [[Jessie Ball duPont Fund]].[http://stjohnscathedralschool.com/] St. John's Cathedral School website, About Us ==Café== ''Clara's at the Cathedral Café'' is a cooperative project between the Cathedral and the School of Culinary Arts at the [[Clara White Mission]]. Every Friday since April 13, 2007, a luncheon has been prepared by the students and staff from the Mission's culinary school. The meal is very reasonably priced and attracts workers from downtown businesses and retirees.{{cite web |url=http://diocesefl.org/stjohnscathedral/topic-page.php?page=182 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725235436/http://diocesefl.org/stjohnscathedral/topic-page.php?page=182 |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }} St. Johns Cathedral webpage, Helping our Neighbors [[Image:StJohnsCathedralJaxTower.PNG|thumb|left|200px|Tower]] [[Image:StJohnsCathedralJaxFront.PNG|thumb|center|200px|Front]] ==See also== *[[List of the Episcopal cathedrals of the United States]] *[[List of cathedrals in the United States]] *[[Episcopal High School of Jacksonville]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category inline|St. John's Cathedral (Jacksonville, Florida)}} *[http://www.jaxcathedral.org/ St. John’s Cathedral, Jacksonville website] *[http://www.stjohnscathedralschool.com/ St. John's Cathedral School website] *[http://www.diocesefl.org/ The Diocese of Florida website] *[http://Florida.anglican.org/ The Episcopal Diocese of Florida] *[http://miller.michael.j.home.comcast.net/sjc_music_index.htm St. John's Music information] *[http://www.demorgan.com/organ.htm Cathedral Organ Layout] *[http://www.episcopalhigh.org/ Episcopal High School] {{Coord|30.328772|-81.653423|display=title}} {{Jacksonville attractions}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Saint Johns Cathedral, Jacksonville}} [[Category:Episcopal churches in Jacksonville, Florida]] [[Category:Episcopal cathedrals in Florida|John Jacksonville]] [[Category:Episcopal church buildings in Florida]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1834]] [[Category:1834 establishments in Florida Territory]] [[Category:Churches completed in 1906]] [[Category:Downtown Jacksonville]]

{{Use British English|date=March 2012}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name=Susana Chou Vaz da Luz
''Chou Kei Jan'' | native_name = {{nobold|曹其真}} | native_name_lang = zh-hant |honorific-suffix = [[Orders, decorations, and medals of Macau|GML]], [[Order of Merit (Portugal)|GCM]], [[Order of Entrepreneurial Merit|ComMA]], [[Order of Entrepreneurial Merit|ComMI]] | image= Susana Chou 20040612.jpg | caption= | nationality= Chinese | order= | office=[[President of the Legislative Assembly of Macau]] | term_start=20 December 1999 | term_end=15 October 2009 | predecessor = [[Anabela Fátima Xavier Sales Ritchie]] | successor = [[Lau Cheok Va]] | alma_mater= [[Anhui University]]
[[University of Paris]] | ancestry = [[Ningbo]], Zhejiang | profession= chartered accountant | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1941|12|3}} | birth_place = Shanghai, China | death_date= | death_place= | spouse= | children= | party= }} {{Chinese|c=曹其真|p=Cáo Qízhēn|cy=Chòuh Kèih Jān}} '''Susana Chou Vaz da Luz''' (born 2 December 1941, Shanghai), also known as '''Chou Kei Jan''' and '''Cao Qizhen''', was the [[President of the Legislative Assembly of Macau]] from 1999 to 2009.XinhuaNet: [http://news.xinhuanet.com/ziliao/2002-03/07/content_305647.htm Brief biography of Susana Chou] ==Biography== Chou's ancestral hometown is the current [[Yinzhou District, Ningbo|Yinzhou District]] of the city of [[Ningbo]] in China's [[Zhejiang Province]]. Chou was born in Shanghai on 2 December 1941, and is the oldest daughter of [[Chao Kuang Piu]], who is an [[business magnate|industrial tycoon]] in Shanghai. While her father moved in Hong Kong after 1949, Chou remained in China until 1968 when she moved to Macau. Chou studied physics and majored in radio technology at the [[Anhui University]]. Chou also studied French language and literature in Paris.[[Baidu]].com Encyclopedia: [http://baike.baidu.com/view/121420.htm Biography of Susana Chou] ==Politics== In 1976, Chou participated in Portuguese Macau's first direct election of the Legislative Assembly, and was successful in the election. From 1984 to 1999, she served in the third, fourth, fifth and sixth sessions of Portuguese Macau's Legislative Assembly. After the [[Transfer of sovereignty of Macau|transfer of sovereignty of Macau from Portugal to China]] in 1999, Chou was elected as the President of new Legislative Assembly for its first, second and third sessions. ==Election results== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:0.5em ; font-size:95%" !|Year !|Candidate !|Hare quota !|Mandate !|List Votes !|List Pct |- |[[Macanese legislative election, 1976|1976]] |bgcolor="red" |{{nowrap|'''Susana Chou Vaz da Luz'''}} (ADIM) |bgcolor="red" align="right" |374 |bgcolor="red" |[[Directly elected member (Macau)|№5/6]] |bgcolor="red" align="right" |1,497 |bgcolor="red" |54.95% |- |[[Macanese legislative election, 1984|1984]] |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" |{{nowrap|'''Susana Chou Vaz da Luz'''}} |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" align="right" |''uncontested'' |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" |[[Functional constituency (Macau)|FC]] |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" align="right" |''uncontested'' |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" |∅ |- |[[Macanese legislative election, 1988|1988]] |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" |{{nowrap|'''Susana Chou Vaz da Luz'''}} |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" align="right" |''walkover'' |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" |[[Functional constituency (Macau)|FC]] |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" align="right" |''walkover'' |bgcolor="{{Nonpartisan/meta/color}}" |∅ |- |[[Macanese legislative election, 1992|1992]] |bgcolor="{{Unity for the Future of Macau/meta/color}}" |{{nowrap|'''Susana Chou Vaz da Luz'''}} (UNIF) |bgcolor="{{Unity for the Future of Macau/meta/color}}" align="right" |2,201 |bgcolor="{{Unity for the Future of Macau/meta/color}}" |[[Directly elected member (Macau)|№6/8]] |bgcolor="{{Unity for the Future of Macau/meta/color}}" align="right" |2,201 |bgcolor="{{Unity for the Future of Macau/meta/color}}" |7.99% |- |[[Macanese legislative election, 1996|1996]]
